eng: I thought him very plain at first, but I do not think him so plain now. ~~~ One does not, you know, after a time.
fr: -- Il n'est pas beau ; au premier abord, je le trouvais meme laid, mais j'ai change d'avis ; on s'habitue tres bien a sa physionomie.

eng: But did you never see him?
fr: Ne l'avez-vous donc jamais vu ?

eng: He is in Highbury every now and then, and he is sure to ride through every week in his way to Kingston.
fr: Il vient assez souvent a Highbury et de toute facon il traverse la ville au moins une fois par semaine pour aller a Kingston.

eng: He has passed you very often."
fr: Il a bien des fois passe a cheval aupres de vous.

eng: "That may be, and I may have seen him fifty times, but without having any idea of his name.
A young farmer, whether on horseback or on foot, is the very last sort of person to raise my curiosity.

The yeomanry are precisely the order of people with whom I feel I can have nothing to do. ~~~ A degree or two lower, and a creditable appearance might interest me; I might hope to be useful to their families in some way or other. ~~~ But a farmer can need none of my help, and is, therefore, in one sense, as much above my notice as in every other he is below it."
fr: -- C'est bien possible ; j'ai pu le voir cinquante fois sans chercher a connaitre son nom : un jeune fermier a pied ou a cheval est la derniere personne qui puisse eveiller ma curiosite ; il appartient precisement a une classe sociale avec laquelle je n'ai aucun point de contact ; a un ou deux echelons au-dessus, je pourrais remarquer un homme a cause de sa bonne mine : je penserais pouvoir etre utile a sa famille, mais un fermier ne peut avoir besoin de mon aide en aucune maniere.

eng: "To be sure.
fr: -- Evidemment !

eng: Oh yes! ~~~ It is not likely you should ever have observed him; but he knows you very well indeed--I mean by sight."
fr: Vous ne l'avez sans doute jamais remarque, mais lui vous connait parfaitement de vue.

eng: "I have no doubt of his being a very respectable young man.
I know, indeed, that he is so, and, as such, wish him well.
fr: -- Je sais que ce jeune homme ne manque pas de merite.

eng: What do you imagine his age to be?"
fr: Savez-vous quel age il peut avoir ?

eng: "He was four-and-twenty the 8th of last June, and my birthday is the 23rd just a fortnight and a day's difference--which is very odd." ~~~ "Only four-and-twenty.
fr: -- Il a eu vingt-quatre ans le 8 juin dernier, et - n'est-ce pas curieux - mon anniversaire tombe le vingt-trois !

eng: That is too young to settle.
fr: -- Seulement vingt-quatre ans ?

eng: His mother is perfectly right not to be in a hurry. ~~~ They seem very comfortable as they are, and if she were to take any pains to marry him, she would probably repent it.
fr: C'est trop jeune pour se marier, et sa mere a parfaitement raison de ne pas le desirer.

eng: Six years hence, if he could meet with a good sort of young woman in the same rank as his own, with a little money, it might be very desirable." ~~~ "Six years hence!
fr: Ils paraissent tres heureux en famille pour le moment ; dans cinq ou six ans, s'il peut rencontrer dans son milieu, une jeune fille avec un peu d'argent, ce sera alors le moment de penser au mariage.

eng: Dear Miss Woodhouse, he would be thirty years old!"
fr: -- Dans six ans, chere mademoiselle Woodhouse, il aura trente ans !

eng: "Well, and that is as early as most men can afford to marry, who are not born to an independence.
fr: -- Un homme qui n'est pas ne independant ne peut guere se permettre de fonder une famille avant cet age.

eng: Mr. Martin, I imagine, has his fortune entirely to make--cannot be at all beforehand with the world.
fr: Quelle que soit la somme dont M. Martin ait herite a la mort de son pere et sa part dans la propriete de famille tout doit etre immobilise par son exploitation.

eng: Whatever money he might come into when his father died, whatever his share of the family property, it is, I dare say, all afloat, all employed in his stock, and so forth; and though, with diligence and good luck, he may be rich in time, it is next to impossible that he should have realised any thing yet."
"To be sure, so it is. ~~~ But they live very comfortably.
fr: Je ne doute pas qu'il ne soit riche un jour mais il ne doit pas l'etre actuellement.

eng: They have no indoors man, else they do not want for any thing; and Mrs. Martin talks of taking a boy another year."
fr: -- C'est ainsi, je crois ; neanmoins, ils vivent tres confortablement ; ils n'ont pas de domestique male ; a cette exception pres, ils ne manquent de rien et meme Mme Martin a l'intention de prendre un jeune garcon a son service l'annee prochaine.

eng: "I wish you may not get into a scrape, Harriet, whenever he does marry;--I mean, as to being acquainted with his wife--for though his sisters, from a superior education, are not to be altogether objected to, it does not follow that he might marry any body at all fit for you to notice.
fr: -- J'espere, Harriet, que vous n'aurez pas d'ennuis a l'occasion du mariage de M. Martin ; il ne s'ensuit pas, en effet, de ce que vous ayez des relations d'amitie avec ses soeurs, que la femme, Mme R. Martin, soit pour vous une connaissance convenable.

eng: The misfortune of your birth ought to make you particularly careful as to your associates.
fr: Le malheur de votre naissance doit vous rendre particulierement attentive a choisir votre entourage.

eng: There can be no doubt of your being a gentleman's daughter, and you must support your claim to that station by every thing within your own power, or there will be plenty of people who would take pleasure in degrading you." ~~~ "Yes, to be sure, I suppose there are.
fr: Vous etes certainement la fille d'un homme comme il faut, et vous devez vous efforcer de conserver votre rang, sinon il ne manquera pas de gens pour essayer de vous degrader.

eng: But while I visit at Hartfield, and you are so kind to me, Miss Woodhouse, I am not afraid of what any body can do."
fr: -- Aussi longtemps que je serai invitee a Hartfield et que vous serez si bonne pour moi, je ne crains rien.

eng: "You understand the force of influence pretty well, Harriet; but I would have you so firmly established in good society, as to be independent even of Hartfield and Miss Woodhouse.
fr: -- Je constate que vous vous rendez compte, Harriet, de l'importance d'etre bien appuyee, mais je voudrais vous voir etablie dans la bonne societe independamment de Hartfield et de Mlle Woodhouse.

eng: I want to see you permanently well connected, and to that end it will be advisable to have as few odd acquaintance as may be; and, therefore, I say that if you should still be in this country when Mr. Martin marries, I wish you may not be drawn in by your intimacy with the sisters, to be acquainted with the wife, who will probably be some mere farmer's daughter, without education." ~~~ "To be sure.
fr: Pour obtenir ce resultat, il sera desirable d'ecarter autant que possible les anciennes connaissances ; si vous etes encore ici a l'epoque du mariage de M. Martin, ne vous laissez donc pas entrainer a faire la connaissance de sa femme qui sera probablement la fille de quelque fermier et une personne sans education.

eng: Yes. ~~~ Not that I think Mr. Martin would ever marry any body but what had had some education--and been very well brought up.
fr: -- C'est juste : je ne crois pas pourtant que M. Martin voudrait epouser une personne qui ne fut pas parfaitement elevee.

eng: However, I do not mean to set up my opinion against yours--and I am sure I shall not wish for the acquaintance of his wife. ~~~ I shall always have a great regard for the Miss Martins, especially Elizabeth, and should be very sorry to give them up, for they are quite as well educated as me. ~~~ But if he marries a very ignorant, vulgar woman, certainly I had better not visit her, if I can help it."
fr: Bien entendu, je n'ai pas l'intention de vous contredire, et je suis sure que je ne desirerai pas connaitre sa femme ; j'aurai toujours de l'amitie pour les demoiselles Martin, surtout pour Elisabeth, que je serais bien fachee d'abandonner ; elles sont tout aussi bien elevees que moi, mais si leur frere epouse une femme ignorante et vulgaire, j'eviterai de la rencontrer, a moins d'y etre forcee.

eng: Emma watched her through the fluctuations of this speech, and saw no alarming symptoms of love. ~~~ The young man had been the first admirer, but she trusted there was no other hold, and that there would be no serious difficulty, on Harriet's side, to oppose any friendly arrangement of her own.
fr: Emma observait Harriet et ne discerna aucun symptome veritablement alarmant : rien n'indiquait que les racines de cette sympathie fussent bien profondes.

eng: They met Mr. Martin the very next day, as they were walking on the Donwell road.
fr: Le lendemain, en se promenant sur la route de Donwell, elles rencontrerent M. Martin.

eng: He was on foot, and after looking very respectfully at her, looked with most unfeigned satisfaction at her companion. ~~~ Emma was not sorry to have such an opportunity of survey; and walking a few yards forward, while they talked together, soon made her quick eye sufficiently acquainted with Mr. Robert Martin. ~~~ His appearance was very neat, and he looked like a sensible young man, but his person had no other advantage; and when he came to be contrasted with gentlemen, she thought he must lose all the ground he had gained in Harriet's inclination.
fr: Il etait a pied et, apres avoir salue respectueusement Emma, il regarda Harriet avec une satisfaction non deguisee ; celle-ci s'arreta pour lui parler, et Emma continua sa route ; au bout de quelques pas, elle se retourna pour examiner le groupe et elle eut vite fait de se rendre compte de l'apparence de M. Martin ; sa mise etait soignee et ses manieres decentes ; rien de plus.

eng: Harriet was not insensible of manner; she had voluntarily noticed her father's gentleness with admiration as well as wonder. ~~~ Mr. Martin looked as if he did not know what manner was.
fr: Emma savait qu'Harriet avait ete frappee de l'exquise urbanite de M. Woodhouse et elle ne doutait pas que celle-ci ne s'apercut du manque d'elegance de M. Martin.

eng: They remained but a few minutes together, as Miss Woodhouse must not be kept waiting; and Harriet then came running to her with a smiling face, and in a flutter of spirits, which Miss Woodhouse hoped very soon to compose.
fr: Au bout de quelques minutes, les deux jeunes gens se separerent, et Harriet rejoignit Emma en courant, la figure rayonnante ; elle dit aussitot : << Quelle curieuse coincidence !

eng: "Only think of our happening to meet him!--How very odd!
It was quite a chance, he said, that he had not gone round by Randalls.
fr: C'est tout a fait par hasard, m'a-t-il dit, qu'il a pris cette route.

eng: He did not think we ever walked this road.

He thought we walked towards Randalls most days. ~~~ He has not been able to get the Romance of the Forest yet. ~~~ He was so busy the last time he was at Kingston that he quite forgot it, but he goes again to-morrow.
fr: Il n'a pas encore pu se procurer la << Romance de la foret >>, il a ete si occupe pendant son dernier voyage a Kingston, qu'il a tout a fait oublie, mais il y retourne demain.

eng: So very odd we should happen to meet!
fr: Eh bien !

eng: Well, Miss Woodhouse, is he like what you expected?
fr: Mlle Woodhouse, l'imaginiez-vous ainsi ?

eng: What do you think of him?
fr: Quelle est votre opinion ?

eng: Do you think him so very plain?"
fr: Le trouvez-vous laid ?

eng: "He is very plain, undoubtedly--remarkably plain:--but that is nothing compared with his entire want of gentility.
fr: -- Sans doute, il n'est pas beau, mais ce n'est qu'un detail en comparaison de son manque de distinction.

eng: I had no right to expect much, and I did not expect much; but I had no idea that he could be so very clownish, so totally without air. ~~~ I had imagined him, I confess, a degree or two nearer gentility."
fr: Je n'etais pas en droit de m'attendre a grand chose mais j'avoue que je le croyais place a deux ou trois echelons plus haut sur l'echelle sociale.

eng: "To be sure," said Harriet, in a mortified voice, "he is not so genteel as real gentlemen."
fr: -- Evidemment, dit Harriet toute mortifiee, il n'a pas la bonne grace d'un homme du monde.

eng: "I think, Harriet, since your acquaintance with us, you have been repeatedly in the company of some such very real gentlemen, that you must yourself be struck with the difference in Mr. Martin.
fr: -- Vous avez, Harriet, rencontre a Hartfield, quelques hommes veritablement comme il faut et vous devez vous rendre compte vous-meme de la difference qui existe entre eux et M. Martin.

eng: At Hartfield, you have had very good specimens of well educated, well bred men.
fr: Vous devez etre etonnee d'avoir pu a aucun moment le juger favorablement.

eng: I should be surprized if, after seeing them, you could be in company with Mr. Martin again without perceiving him to be a very inferior creature--and rather wondering at yourself for having ever thought him at all agreeable before. ~~~ Do not you begin to feel that now? ~~~ Were not you struck?
I am sure you must have been struck by his awkward look and abrupt manner, and the uncouthness of a voice which I heard to be wholly unmodulated as I stood here."
fr: Vous avez certainement remarque son air emprunte, ses manieres frustes et son langage vulgaire ?

eng: "Certainly, he is not like Mr. Knightley. ~~~ He has not such a fine air and way of walking as Mr. Knightley.
fr: -- Certainement, il ne ressemble pas a M. Knightley : il n'a ni le port, ni les manieres de M. Knightley.

eng: I see the difference plain enough. ~~~ But Mr. Knightley is so very fine a man!"
fr: Je vois la difference clairement... mais M. Knightley est particulierement elegant.

eng: "Mr. Knightley's air is so remarkably good that it is not fair to compare Mr. Martin with _him_.
fr: -- M. Knightley a si grand air qu'il ne serait pas equitable de l'opposer a M. Martin.

eng: You might not see one in a hundred with _gentleman_ so plainly written as in Mr. Knightley.
fr: Vous avez ete a meme d'observer d'autres hommes bien eleves : M. Weston et M. Elton, par exemple ?

eng: But he is not the only gentleman you have been lately used to.
What say you to Mr. Weston and Mr. Elton?
fr: Faites la comparaison.

eng: Compare Mr. Martin with either of _them_.
Compare their manner of carrying themselves; of walking; of speaking; of being silent.
fr: Quelle difference dans le maintien, dans la maniere d'ecouter et de parler !

eng: You must see the difference."
"Oh yes!--there is a great difference. ~~~ But Mr. Weston is almost an old man.
fr: -- Vous avez raison, mais M. Weston est un homme age : il a pres de cinquante ans.

eng: Mr. Weston must be between forty and fifty." ~~~ "Which makes his good manners the more valuable.
fr: -- C'est l'age ou les bonnes manieres ont le plus d'importance ; le manque d'aisance devient alors plus apparent.

eng: The older a person grows, Harriet, the more important it is that their manners should not be bad; the more glaring and disgusting any loudness, or coarseness, or awkwardness becomes.
What is passable in youth is detestable in later age. ~~~ Mr. Martin is now awkward and abrupt; what will he be at Mr. Weston's time of life?"
fr: M. Martin parait vulgaire, malgre sa jeunesse ; que sera-ce lorsqu'il aura atteint l'age de M. Weston ?

eng: "There is no saying, indeed," replied Harriet rather solemnly.
fr: -- Votre remarque est juste, dit Harriet d'un air grave.

eng: "But there may be pretty good guessing.
fr: -- Il deviendra un gros fermier uniquement preoccupe de ses interets.

eng: He will be a completely gross, vulgar farmer, totally inattentive to appearances, and thinking of nothing but profit and loss." ~~~ "Will he, indeed?
That will be very bad."
fr: -- Est-ce possible ?

eng: "How much his business engrosses him already is very plain from the circumstance of his forgetting to inquire for the book you recommended.
He was a great deal too full of the market to think of any thing else--which is just as it should be, for a thriving man.
What has he to do with books?
fr: Ce serait epouvantable !

eng: And I have no doubt that he _will_ thrive, and be a very rich man in time--and his being illiterate and coarse need not disturb _us_." ~~~ "I wonder he did not remember the book"--was all Harriet's answer, and spoken with a degree of grave displeasure which Emma thought might be safely left to itself. ~~~ She, therefore, said no more for some time.
fr: -- Le fait d'avoir oublie de se procurer le livre que vous lui aviez recommande indique suffisamment combien ses devoirs professionnels l'absorbent deja ; il etait beaucoup trop occupe des fluctuations du marche pour penser a autre chose, ce qui est fort naturel chez un homme qui gagne sa vie.

eng: Her next beginning was, "In one respect, perhaps, Mr. Elton's manners are superior to Mr. Knightley's or Mr. Weston's.
They have more gentleness. ~~~ They might be more safely held up as a pattern.
fr: -- Je suis etonnee qu'il ait oublie le livre, dit Harriet d'un ton de regret.

eng: There is an openness, a quickness, almost a bluntness in Mr. Weston, which every body likes in _him_, because there is so much good-humour with it--but that would not do to be copied.
fr: Apres avoir laisse a Harriet le temps de mediter sur cette negligence, Emma reprit : << A un certain point de vue on peut dire que les manieres de M. Elton sont superieures a celles de M. Knightley et de M. Weston.

eng: Neither would Mr. Knightley's downright, decided, commanding sort of manner, though it suits _him_ very well; his figure, and look, and situation in life seem to allow it; but if any young man were to set about copying him, he would not be sufferable.
fr: Il y a chez ce dernier une vivacite, une sorte de brusquerie qui s'adaptent a son temperament chez lui, mais il ne conviendrait pas de l'imiter ; de meme la maniere decidee, imperieuse de M. Knightley s'accorde parfaitement avec son esprit, sa taille et sa situation sociale ; pourtant si un jeune homme s'avisait de l'adopter, il ne serait pas supportable.

eng: On the contrary, I think a young man might be very safely recommended to take Mr. Elton as a model. ~~~ Mr. Elton is good-humoured, cheerful, obliging, and gentle.
fr: Je crois, au contraire, qu'on pourrait proposer M. Elton comme modele : M. Elton a des manieres affables, un caractere gai, obligeant et doux.

eng: He seems to me to be grown particularly gentle of late. ~~~ I do not know whether he has any design of ingratiating himself with either of us, Harriet, by additional softness, but it strikes me that his manners are softer than they used to be.
fr: Il me semble meme que, depuis quelque temps, il se montre particulierement aimable ; je ne sais s'il a le projet de se faire bien venir d'une de nous ; dans ce cas, c'est evidemment en votre honneur qu'il se met en frais de galanterie.

eng: If he means any thing, it must be to please you. ~~~ Did not I tell you what he said of you the other day?"
fr: Vous ai-je repete tous les compliments qu'il m'a faits de vous l'autre jour ?

eng: She then repeated some warm personal praise which she had drawn from Mr. Elton, and now did full justice to; and Harriet blushed and smiled, and said she had always thought Mr. Elton very agreeable.
Mr. Elton was the very person fixed on by Emma for driving the young farmer out of Harriet's head.
fr: >> Emma en rapportant ces propos flatteurs omit de dire qu'elle les avait encourages.

eng: She thought it would be an excellent match; and only too palpably desirable, natural, and probable, for her to have much merit in planning it. ~~~ She feared it was what every body else must think of and predict.
fr: Harriet rougit de plaisir et protesta avoir toujours trouve M. Elton tres agreable ; ce dernier etait precisement la personne sur laquelle Emma avait jete son devolu pour faire oublier a Harriet son jeune fermier.

eng: It was not likely, however, that any body should have equalled her in the date of the plan, as it had entered her brain during the very first evening of Harriet's coming to Hartfield.
fr: La position sociale de M. Elton lui paraissait particulierement adaptee a la situation ; il etait tres comme il faut, sans pourtant appartenir a une famille que la naissance irreguliere d'Harriet pourrait offusquer.

eng: The longer she considered it, the greater was her sense of its expediency.
fr: Les revenus personnels du jeune vicaire devaient etre suffisants car la cure de Hartfield n'etait pas importante.

eng: Mr. Elton's situation was most suitable, quite the gentleman himself, and without low connexions; at the same time, not of any family that could fairly object to the doubtful birth of Harriet.
fr: Elle avait une tres bonne opinion de lui et le considerait comme un jeune homme d'avenir.

eng: He had a comfortable home for her, and Emma imagined a very sufficient income; for though the vicarage of Highbury was not large, he was known to have some independent property; and she thought very highly of him as a good-humoured, well-meaning, respectable young man, without any deficiency of useful understanding or knowledge of the world.
fr: Elle ne doutait pas qu'il n'admirat beaucoup Harriet et elle comptait sur de frequentes rencontres a Hartfield pour developper ce sentiment ; quant a Harriet, il lui suffirait sans doute de s'apercevoir de la preference dont elle serait l'objet pour l'apprecier aussitot a sa juste valeur.

eng: She had already satisfied herself that he thought Harriet a beautiful girl, which she trusted, with such frequent meetings at Hartfield, was foundation enough on his side; and on Harriet's there could be little doubt that the idea of being preferred by him would have all the usual weight and efficacy.

And he was really a very pleasing young man, a young man whom any woman not fastidious might like. ~~~ He was reckoned very handsome; his person much admired in general, though not by her, there being a want of elegance of feature which she could not dispense with:--but the girl who could be gratified by a Robert Martin's riding about the country to get walnuts for her might very well be conquered by Mr. Elton's admiration.
fr: M. Elton, du reste, pouvait legitimement avoir la pretention de plaire a la plupart des femmes ; il passait pour un tres bel homme ; Emma pour sa part ne partageait pas l'opinion generale, elle jugeait que le visage de M. Elton manquait d'une certaine noblesse qu'elle prisait par dessus tout ; mais il lui paraissait evident que la jeune fille qui avait pu etre flattee des attentions de Robert Martin serait vite conquise par les hommages de M. Elton.

eng: CHAPTER V "I do not know what your opinion may be, Mrs. Weston," said Mr. Knightley, "of this great intimacy between Emma and Harriet Smith, but I think it a bad thing." ~~~ "A bad thing!
fr: V -- Je ne sais quelle est votre opinion, Mme Weston, dit M. Knightley, sur l'intimite qui est en train de s'etablir entre Emma et Henriette Smith.

eng: Do you really think it a bad thing?--why so?"
fr: Quant a moi, je ne l'approuve pas.

eng: "I think they will neither of them do the other any good."
"You surprize me!
fr: -- Vraiment !

eng: Emma must do Harriet good: and by supplying her with a new object of interest, Harriet may be said to do Emma good.
fr: Et pourquoi ? ~~~ -- Je crains qu'elles n'aient une facheuse influence l'une sur l'autre.

eng: I have been seeing their intimacy with the greatest pleasure. ~~~ How very differently we feel!--Not think they will do each other any good!
fr: -- Vous m'etonnez, Harriet ne peut que gagner a ce contact et d'autre part, en devenant pour Emma un objet d'interet, elle rendra indirectement service a son amie.

eng: This will certainly be the beginning of one of our quarrels about Emma, Mr. ~~~ Knightley."
fr: Je prevois que cette divergence d'opinions va servir de preface a une de nos querelles a propos d'Emma.

eng: "Perhaps you think I am come on purpose to quarrel with you, knowing Weston to be out, and that you must still fight your own battle."
fr: -- Vous l'avez devine sans doute : je profite de l'absence de M. Weston pour livrer bataille.

eng: "Mr. Weston would undoubtedly support me, if he were here, for he thinks exactly as I do on the subject.
fr: Il faut que vous vous defendiez toute seule comme autrefois.

eng: We were speaking of it only yesterday, and agreeing how fortunate it was for Emma, that there should be such a girl in Highbury for her to associate with. ~~~ Mr. Knightley, I shall not allow you to be a fair judge in this case.
fr: -- M. Weston, s'il etait la, serait assurement de mon cote, car il partage entierement ma maniere de voir : nous parlions precisement d'Emma, hier soir, et nous etions d'accord pour considerer comme une bonne fortune qu'il se soit trouve, a Hartfield, une jeune fille en situation de lui tenir compagnie.

eng: You are so much used to live alone, that you do not know the value of a companion; and, perhaps no man can be a good judge of the comfort a woman feels in the society of one of her own sex, after being used to it all her life.
fr: Du reste, Monsieur Knightley, je vous recuse comme juge en cette affaire : vous etes si habitue a vivre seul que vous ne pouvez pas vous rendre compte du reconfort qu'une femme trouve dans la societe d'une de ses semblables.

eng: I can imagine your objection to Harriet Smith. ~~~ She is not the superior young woman which Emma's friend ought to be. ~~~ But on the other hand, as Emma wants to see her better informed, it will be an inducement to her to read more herself.
fr: Je vois venir votre objection relativement a Harriet Smith : ce n'est pas la jeune fille superieure que devrait etre l'amie d'Emma... je l'accorde ; mais d'autre part, je sais qu'Emma se propose de lire avec Harriet, ce sera pour elle une occasion de s'occuper serieusement.

eng: They will read together. ~~~ She means it, I know."
fr: -- Depuis qu'elle a douze ans, Emma a l'intention de s'adonner a la lecture.

eng: "Emma has been meaning to read more ever since she was twelve years old.
fr: Elle a dresse a differentes epoques la liste des ouvrages qu'elle voulait lire.

eng: I have seen a great many lists of her drawing-up at various times of books that she meant to read regularly through--and very good lists they were--very well chosen, and very neatly arranged--sometimes alphabetically, and sometimes by some other rule.
fr: Je me rappelle avoir conserve un plan d'etudes compose a quatorze ans et qui faisait honneur a son jugement.

eng: The list she drew up when only fourteen--I remember thinking it did her judgment so much credit, that I preserved it some time; and I dare say she may have made out a very good list now.
fr: Mais j'ai renonce a attendre d'Emma un effort serieux dans ce sens ; jamais elle ne se soumettra a un travail qui exige de la patience et de la suite.

eng: But I have done with expecting any course of steady reading from Emma.
fr: A coup sur la ou Mlle Taylor a echoue, Harriet Smith ne reussira pas !

eng: She will never submit to any thing requiring industry and patience, and a subjection of the fancy to the understanding.
fr: Vous savez bien que vous n'avez jamais pu obtenir qu'elle consacrat a la lecture le temps necessaire.

eng: Where Miss Taylor failed to stimulate, I may safely affirm that Harriet Smith will do nothing.--You never could persuade her to read half so much as you wished.--You know you could not."
fr: -- Il est possible, repondit Mme Weston en souriant, que tel ait ete mon avis a cette epoque, mais depuis notre separation j'ai perdu tout souvenir qu'Emma ait jamais refuse de complaire a mes desirs.

eng: "I dare say," replied Mrs. Weston, smiling, "that I thought so _then_;--but since we have parted, I can never remember Emma's omitting to do any thing I wished."
fr: -- Il serait cruel de chercher a guerir ce genre d'amnesie, repondit M. Knightley affectueusement, mais moi dont aucun charme n'a emousse les sens, je vois, j'entends et je me rappelle.

eng: "There is hardly any desiring to refresh such a memory as _that_,"--said Mr. Knightley, feelingly; and for a moment or two he had done. ~~~ "But I," he soon added, "who have had no such charm thrown over my senses, must still see, hear, and remember. ~~~ Emma is spoiled by being the cleverest of her family.
fr: Ce qui a gate Emma c'est d'etre la plus intelligente de sa famille ; elle a toujours fait preuve de vivacite d'esprit et d'assurance : Isabelle, au contraire, etait timide et d'intelligence moyenne.

eng: At ten years old, she had the misfortune of being able to answer questions which puzzled her sister at seventeen.
She was always quick and assured: Isabella slow and diffident.
fr: Depuis l'age de douze ans, c'est la volonte d'Emma qui a prevalu a Hartfield.

eng: And ever since she was twelve, Emma has been mistress of the house and of you all.
fr: En perdant sa mere, elle a perdu la seule personne qui aurait pu lui tenir tete.

eng: In her mother she lost the only person able to cope with her.
She inherits her mother's talents, and must have been under subjection to her."
fr: Elle a herite de l'intelligence de Mme Woodhouse, mais le joug maternel lui a manque.

eng: "I should have been sorry, Mr. Knightley, to be dependent on _your_ recommendation, had I quitted Mr. Woodhouse's family and wanted another situation; I do not think you would have spoken a good word for me to any body.
fr: -- Si j'avais quitte la famille de M. Woodhouse pour chercher une autre situation, je n'aurais pas voulu dependre d'une recommandation de votre part ; vous n'auriez fait mes eloges a personne et je me rends compte que vous m'avez toujours jugee inferieure a la charge que j'avais assumee.

eng: I am sure you always thought me unfit for the office I held."
fr: -- Oui, dit-il en souriant, vous etes plus a votre place ici.

eng: "Yes," said he, smiling. ~~~ "You are better placed _here_; very fit for a wife, but not at all for a governess.
fr: Vous vous prepariez, pendant votre sejour a Hartfield, a devenir une epouse modele.

eng: But you were preparing yourself to be an excellent wife all the time you were at Hartfield. ~~~ You might not give Emma such a complete education as your powers would seem to promise; but you were receiving a very good education from _her_, on the very material matrimonial point of submitting your own will, and doing as you were bid; and if Weston had asked me to recommend him a wife, I should certainly have named Miss Taylor."
fr: Sans doute, vous n'avez peut-etre pas donne a Emma une education aussi complete qu'auraient pu le faire supposer vos capacites ; mais, en revanche, vous appreniez d'elle a plier votre volonte pour la soumission conjugale ; si M. Weston m'avait consulte a la veille de prendre femme, je n'aurais pas manque de lui indiquer Mlle Taylor.

eng: "Thank you.
fr: -- Merci.

eng: There will be very little merit in making a good wife to such a man as Mr. ~~~ Weston."
fr: Il y aura, du reste, peu de merite a etre une femme devouee avec un mari comme M. Weston.

eng: "Why, to own the truth, I am afraid you are rather thrown away, and that with every disposition to bear, there will be nothing to be borne.
fr: -- A dire vrai, je crains, en effet, que vous ne soyez pas appelee a donner la mesure de votre abnegation.

eng: We will not despair, however. ~~~ Weston may grow cross from the wantonness of comfort, or his son may plague him."
fr: Ne desesperons pas pourtant : Weston peut devenir grognon a force de bien-etre ; son fils peut lui causer des ennuis.

eng: "I hope not _that_.--It is not likely. ~~~ No, Mr. Knightley, do not foretell vexation from that quarter."
fr: -- Je vous prie, monsieur Knightley, ne prevoyez pas de tourment de ce cote.

eng: "Not I, indeed. ~~~ I only name possibilities.
fr: -- Mes suppositions sont toutes gratuites.

eng: I do not pretend to Emma's genius for foretelling and guessing.
fr: Je ne pretends pas aucunement avoir la clairvoyance d'Emma, ni son genie de prophetie.

eng: I hope, with all my heart, the young man may be a Weston in merit, and a Churchill in fortune.--But Harriet Smith--I have not half done about Harriet Smith.
fr: J'espere de tout mon coeur que le jeune homme tiendra des Weston pour le merite et des Churchill pour la fortune !

eng: I think her the very worst sort of companion that Emma could possibly have.
fr: Mais quant a Harriet Smith - je reviens a mes moutons !

eng: She knows nothing herself, and looks upon Emma as knowing every thing.
fr: - je persiste a la considerer comme tout a fait impropre a tenir aupres d'Emma le role d'amie : elle ne sait rien et considere Emma comme omnisciente !

eng: She is a flatterer in all her ways; and so much the worse, because undesigned.
fr: Toute sa maniere d'etre, a son insu, respire la flatterie.

eng: Her ignorance is hourly flattery. ~~~ How can Emma imagine she has any thing to learn herself, while Harriet is presenting such a delightful inferiority?
fr: Comment Emma pourrait-elle imaginer avoir quelque chose, a apprendre elle-meme, lorsqu'a ses cotes Harriet apparait si delicieusement inferieure !

eng: And as for Harriet, I will venture to say that _she_ cannot gain by the acquaintance.
fr: D'autre part, Harriet ne tirera aucun avantage de cette liaison.

eng: Hartfield will only put her out of conceit with all the other places she belongs to. ~~~ She will grow just refined enough to be uncomfortable with those among whom birth and circumstances have placed her home.
fr: Hartfield lui fera trouver desagreables tous les autres milieux ou elle sera appelee a vivre ; elle deviendra juste assez raffinee pour ne plus etre a l'aise avec ceux parmi lesquels la naissance et les circonstances l'ont placee.

eng: I am much mistaken if Emma's doctrines give any strength of mind, or tend at all to make a girl adapt herself rationally to the varieties of her situation in life.--They only give a little polish."
fr: Je serais bien etonne si les doctrines d'Emma avaient pour resultat de former le caractere tout au plus peuvent-elles donner un leger vernis.

eng: "I either depend more upon Emma's good sense than you do, or am more anxious for her present comfort; for I cannot lament the acquaintance.
fr: -- Est-ce parce que je me fie au bon sens d'Emma, ou bien suis-je avant tout preoccupee de son bien-etre actuel, toujours est-il que je ne puis partager vos craintes.

eng: How well she looked last night!" ~~~ "Oh!
fr: Combien elle etait a son avantage, hier soir !

eng: you would rather talk of her person than her mind, would you?
fr: -- Je devine votre tactique : vous desirez faire devier l'entretien sur les merites corporels d'Emma ?

eng: Very well; I shall not attempt to deny Emma's being pretty."
fr: Eh bien ! ~~~ je vous concede qu'Emma est jolie.

eng: "Pretty!
fr: -- Jolie !

eng: say beautiful rather.
fr: dites plutot parfaitement belle.

eng: Can you imagine any thing nearer perfect beauty than Emma altogether--face and figure?"
"I do not know what I could imagine, but I confess that I have seldom seen a face or figure more pleasing to me than hers.
fr: -- En tout cas je ne connais pas de visage qui me plaise plus, mais je suis un si vieil ami que mon jugement reste entache de partialite.

eng: But I am a partial old friend."
fr: -- Quelle vivacite dans le regard !

eng: "Such an eye!--the true hazle eye--and so brilliant!
fr: Des traits reguliers, un teint eblouissant, une taille parfaite !

eng: regular features, open countenance, with a complexion! ~~~ oh!
fr: On dit parfois qu'un enfant respire la sante : cette expression, il me semble, s'applique dans toute sa plenitude a Emma.

eng: what a bloom of full health, and such a pretty height and size; such a firm and upright figure! ~~~ There is health, not merely in her bloom, but in her air, her head, her glance.
fr: -- Je n'ai rien a redire a sa personne et votre description est exacte ; j'aime a la regarder et j'ajouterai un compliment : je ne la crois pas vaniteuse.

eng: One hears sometimes of a child being 'the picture of health;' now, Emma always gives me the idea of being the complete picture of grown-up health.
fr: Quoiqu'il en soit, Madame Weston, vous n'arriverez pas a me persuader que cette amitie avec Harriet Smith ne soit pas nuisible pour toutes deux.

eng: She is loveliness itself. ~~~ Mr. Knightley, is not she?"
fr: -- Et moi, monsieur Knightley, je reste convaincu qu'il n'en sortira aucun dommage.

eng: "I have not a fault to find with her person," he replied.
fr: Malgre ses petits defauts, Emma est excellente.

eng: "I think her all you describe.
I love to look at her; and I will add this praise, that I do not think her personally vain.
Considering how very handsome she is, she appears to be little occupied with it; her vanity lies another way.
Mrs. Weston, I am not to be talked out of my dislike of Harriet Smith, or my dread of its doing them both harm."
"And I, Mr. Knightley, am equally stout in my confidence of its not doing them any harm.
fr: Ou trouverez-vous une fille plus devouee, une soeur plus affectueuse, une amie plus sure ?

eng: With all dear Emma's little faults, she is an excellent creature.
fr: Quand elle se trompe, elle reconnait vite son erreur.

eng: Where shall we see a better daughter, or a kinder sister, or a truer friend?
fr: -- Je ne vous tourmenterai pas plus longtemps.

eng: No, no; she has qualities which may be trusted; she will never lead any one really wrong; she will make no lasting blunder; where Emma errs once, she is in the right a hundred times."
"Very well; I will not plague you any more.
fr: Admettons qu'Emma soit un ange.

eng: Emma shall be an angel, and I will keep my spleen to myself till Christmas brings John and Isabella.
fr: Je garderai ma mauvaise humeur pour moi jusqu'a ce que Noel amene Jean et Isabelle.

eng: John loves Emma with a reasonable and therefore not a blind affection, and Isabella always thinks as he does; except when he is not quite frightened enough about the children.
fr: Jean aime Emma d'une affection raisonnable qui par consequent n'est pas aveugle, et Isabelle adopte toujours l'avis de son mari, excepte en ce qui concerne la sante et les soins de ses enfants.

eng: I am sure of having their opinions with me."
fr: Je connais d'avance leur opinion.

eng: "I know that you all love her really too well to be unjust or unkind; but excuse me, Mr. Knightley, if I take the liberty (I consider myself, you know, as having somewhat of the privilege of speech that Emma's mother might have had) the liberty of hinting that I do not think any possible good can arise from Harriet Smith's intimacy being made a matter of much discussion among you.
fr: -- Je suis convaincue que vous l'aimez tous trop sincerement pour etre injustes ou severes ; mais permettez-moi, Monsieur Knightley, -- je me considere, vous le savez, comme ayant un peu le privilege de parler au nom de la mere d'Emma, - de vous suggerer les inconvenients qui pourraient surgir de la mise en discussion parmi vous de l'amitie d'Emma pour Harriet.

eng: Pray excuse me; but supposing any little inconvenience may be apprehended from the intimacy, it cannot be expected that Emma, accountable to nobody but her father, who perfectly approves the acquaintance, should put an end to it, so long as it is a source of pleasure to herself.
fr: En supposant qu'il y ait, en effet, quelque chose a redire a cette intimite, il est peu probable qu'Emma qui ne doit compte de sa conduite a personne qu'a son pere, se montre disposee a renoncer a une relation qui lui plait.

eng: It has been so many years my province to give advice, that you cannot be surprized, Mr. Knightley, at this little remains of office." ~~~ "Not at all," cried he; "I am much obliged to you for it.
fr: Pendant tant d'annees, il a ete dans mes attributions de donner des conseils que vous ne serez pas surpris, j'espere, si je n'ai pas tout a fait perdu cette habitude professionnelle.

eng: It is very good advice, and it shall have a better fate than your advice has often found; for it shall be attended to."
fr: -- Du tout, et je vous remercie ; c'est un bon conseil et il aura un meilleur sort que ceux que vous donniez autrefois, car il sera suivi !

eng: "Mrs. John Knightley is easily alarmed, and might be made unhappy about her sister."
fr: -- Mme Jean Knightley se tourmente facilement et je craindrais de lui voir prendre l'affaire trop a coeur.

eng: "Be satisfied," said he, "I will not raise any outcry.
fr: -- Soyez satisfaite : je ne jetterai pas le cri d'alarme.

eng: I will keep my ill-humour to myself.
I have a very sincere interest in Emma.
Isabella does not seem more my sister; has never excited a greater interest; perhaps hardly so great.
fr: J'eprouve pour Emma un sentiment de sincere interet auquel se mele un peu d'inquietude.

eng: There is an anxiety, a curiosity in what one feels for Emma.
I wonder what will become of her!"
fr: Je me demande quelle sera sa destinee !

eng: "So do I," said Mrs. Weston gently, "very much."
fr: -- Cette question me preoccupe beaucoup aussi.

eng: "She always declares she will never marry, which, of course, means just nothing at all.
But I have no idea that she has yet ever seen a man she cared for.
It would not be a bad thing for her to be very much in love with a proper object. ~~~ I should like to see Emma in love, and in some doubt of a return; it would do her good.
fr: -- Elle declare toujours qu'elle ne se mariera jamais, ce qui, naturellement, ne signifie rien ; mais elle n'a pas, je crois, rencontre encore un homme qui lui plaise.

eng: But there is nobody hereabouts to attach her; and she goes so seldom from home." ~~~ "There does, indeed, seem as little to tempt her to break her resolution at present," said Mrs. Weston, "as can well be; and while she is so happy at Hartfield, I cannot wish her to be forming any attachment which would be creating such difficulties on poor Mr. Woodhouse's account.
fr: Je ne vois personne ici qui puisse lui inspirer de l'attachement, et elle s'absente si rarement... -- Il ne semble pas en effet qu'il y ait pour l'instant grand risque de lui voir rompre son voeu et aussi longtemps qu'elle sera si heureuse a Hartfield je ne puis souhaiter de voir sa situation se modifier, par egard pour ce pauvre M. Woodhouse.

eng: I do not recommend matrimony at present to Emma, though I mean no slight to the state, I assure you." ~~~ Part of her meaning was to conceal some favourite thoughts of her own and Mr. Weston's on the subject, as much as possible.
fr: Je ne me fais pas l'avocat du mariage aupres d'Emma pour le moment, bien que je ne puisse etre soupconnee d'avoir des prejuges contre cette institution !

eng: There were wishes at Randalls respecting Emma's destiny, but it was not desirable to have them suspected; and the quiet transition which Mr. Knightley soon afterwards made to "What does Weston think of the weather; shall we have rain?"
fr: Mme Weston avait une arriere-pensee qu'elle s'efforcait de ne pas laisser paraitre : elle et son mari nourrissaient un projet concernant l'avenir d'Emma, mais ils jugeaient desirable de le tenir secret.

eng: convinced her that he had nothing more to say or surmise about Hartfield. ~~~ CHAPTER VI Emma could not feel a doubt of having given Harriet's fancy a proper direction and raised the gratitude of her young vanity to a very good purpose, for she found her decidedly more sensible than before of Mr. Elton's being a remarkably handsome man, with most agreeable manners; and as she had no hesitation in following up the assurance of his admiration by agreeable hints, she was soon pretty confident of creating as much liking on Harriet's side, as there could be any occasion for.
She was quite convinced of Mr. Elton's being in the fairest way of falling in love, if not in love already.
fr: Peu apres, M. Knightley reprit : -- Qu'est-ce que Weston pense du temps ; croit-il qu'il va pleuvoir ?

eng: She had no scruple with regard to him.
fr: et il se leva pour prendre conge.

eng: He talked of Harriet, and praised her so warmly, that she could not suppose any thing wanting which a little time would not add.
fr: VI Emma s'apercut bientot du succes de ses efforts pour donner a l'imagination d'Harriet un nouvel aliment : celle-ci ne tarda pas a apprecier comme il convenait les avantages physiques de M. Elton et l'agrement de ses manieres.

eng: His perception of the striking improvement of Harriet's manner, since her introduction at Hartfield, was not one of the least agreeable proofs of his growing attachment.
fr: D'autre part, elle etait convaincue que ce dernier etait bien pres d'etre amoureux, s'il ne l'etait pas deja.

eng: "You have given Miss Smith all that she required," said he; "you have made her graceful and easy.
fr: Il exprimait son appreciation des progres realises par Harriet depuis sa venue a Hartfield dans des termes qui paraissaient concluants : -- Vous avez donne a Mlle Smith ce qui lui manquait : l'aisance et le gout.

eng: She was a beautiful creature when she came to you, but, in my opinion, the attractions you have added are infinitely superior to what she received from nature."
fr: C'etait une ravissante creature lorsque vous l'avez connue, mais a mon avis les attraits dont vous l'avez ornee surpassent de beaucoup ceux qu'elle devait a la nature.

eng: "I am glad you think I have been useful to her; but Harriet only wanted drawing out, and receiving a few, very few hints.
fr: -- Je suis heureuse de penser que mes conseils lui ont ete utiles ; mais a dire vrai Harriet possedait toutes les aptitudes.

eng: She had all the natural grace of sweetness of temper and artlessness in herself.
fr: Mon oeuvre se reduit a peu de chose.

eng: I have done very little."
fr: -- S'il etait permis de contredire une femme... dit galamment M. Elton.

eng: "If it were admissible to contradict a lady," said the gallant Mr. Elton-- "I have perhaps given her a little more decision of character, have taught her to think on points which had not fallen in her way before."
fr: -- Peut-etre son caractere a-t-il acquis un peu plus de decision : je lui ai suggere quelques points sur lesquels sa pensee n'avait pas l'habitude de s'arreter.

eng: "Exactly so; that is what principally strikes me.
fr: -- Precisement.

eng: So much superadded decision of character!
fr: Et ce resultat a ete obtenu en si peu de temps.

eng: Skilful has been the hand!"
fr: Quelle legerete de touche !

eng: "Great has been the pleasure, I am sure.
fr: -- Dites plutot : quelle culture facile !

eng: I never met with a disposition more truly amiable."
fr: Je n'ai jamais rencontre un esprit plus souple.

eng: "I have no doubt of it."
fr: -- Je n'en doute pas.

eng: And it was spoken with a sort of sighing animation, which had a vast deal of the lover.
fr: Quelques jours apres, au cours d'une conversation, elle demanda a Harriet en presence de M. Elton.

eng: She was not less pleased another day with the manner in which he seconded a sudden wish of hers, to have Harriet's picture.
"Did you ever have your likeness taken, Harriet?"
said she: "did you ever sit for your picture?"
fr: -- A-t-on jamais fait votre portrait Harriet ?

eng: Harriet was on the point of leaving the room, and only stopt to say, with a very interesting naivete, "Oh!
fr: A ce moment, on vint appeler Harriet de la part de Mme Goddard.

eng: dear, no, never." ~~~ No sooner was she out of sight, than Emma exclaimed, "What an exquisite possession a good picture of her would be!
fr: Avant de quitter le salon elle s'arreta une minute pour repondre avec une naivete charmante : -- Mais non, jamais.

eng: I would give any money for it. ~~~ I almost long to attempt her likeness myself.
fr: Des qu'elle fut sortie Emma dit : -- Comme il serait agreable d'avoir un bon portrait d'elle ; j'ai presqu'envie de m'y essayer moi-meme.

eng: You do not know it I dare say, but two or three years ago I had a great passion for taking likenesses, and attempted several of my friends, and was thought to have a tolerable eye in general.
fr: Vous ne le savez pas sans doute, mais il y a deux ou trois ans, je me suis adonnee avec passion a peindre des portraits ; puis le gout m'en est passe.

eng: But from one cause or another, I gave it up in disgust.
But really, I could almost venture, if Harriet would sit to me.
It would be such a delight to have her picture!" ~~~ "Let me entreat you," cried Mr. Elton; "it would indeed be a delight!
fr: Nonobstant si Harriet voulait poser pour moi, je me risquerais encore une fois.

eng: Let me entreat you, Miss Woodhouse, to exercise so charming a talent in favour of your friend.
fr: -- Laissez-moi vous prier, mademoiselle Woodhouse, s'ecria M. Elton, d'exercer votre charmant talent en faveur de votre amie.

eng: I know what your drawings are.
fr: Je connais vos oeuvres.

eng: How could you suppose me ignorant?
fr: Comment pouvez-vous supposer le contraire ?

eng: Is not this room rich in specimens of your landscapes and flowers; and has not Mrs. Weston some inimitable figure-pieces in her drawing-room, at Randalls?"
fr: Ce salon n'est-il pas tapisse de fleurs et de paysages dus a votre pinceau ? ~~~ D'autre part ; j'ai pu examiner chez Mme Weston quelques delicieux specimens de vos dessins.

eng: Yes, good man!--thought Emma--but what has all that to do with taking likenesses?
fr: << Oui, excellent jeune homme, pensa Emma, mais ceci n'a rien a voir avec le don de la ressemblance !

eng: You know nothing of drawing.
fr: Vous n'y entendez rien !

eng: Don't pretend to be in raptures about mine.
fr: Ne simulez pas l'admiration pour ma peinture ; gardez la plutot pour Harriet !

eng: Keep your raptures for Harriet's face.
fr: >> Puis elle reprit : -- Eh bien !

eng: "Well, if you give me such kind encouragement, Mr. Elton, I believe I shall try what I can do. ~~~ Harriet's features are very delicate, which makes a likeness difficult; and yet there is a peculiarity in the shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth which one ought to catch."
fr: Monsieur Elton, puisque vous m'encouragez si aimablement, je crois que je vais essayer mes forces ; les traits d'Harriet sont si fins qu'il sera difficile d'en rendre toute la delicatesse ; cependant il y a dans la forme de l'oeil et dans le contour de la bouche quelque chose de si caracteristique que la ressemblance ne doit pas etre impossible a saisir.

eng: "Exactly so--The shape of the eye and the lines about the mouth--I have not a doubt of your success.
fr: -- Vous dites bien : la forme de l'oeil et de la bouche ! ~~~ Vous reussirez certainement.

eng: Pray, pray attempt it.
fr: Ce sera une oeuvre exquise !

eng: As you will do it, it will indeed, to use your own words, be an exquisite possession." ~~~ "But I am afraid, Mr. Elton, Harriet will not like to sit.
fr: -- Mais je crains bien, Monsieur Elton, qu'Harriet ne se prete pas de bonne grace a ce desir : elle attache si peu d'importance a sa beaute.

eng: She thinks so little of her own beauty. ~~~ Did not you observe her manner of answering me?
fr: N'avez-vous pas observe avec quel detachement elle a repondu a ma question ?

eng: How completely it meant, 'why should my picture be drawn?'" ~~~ "Oh!
fr: C'etait dire : << A quel propos aurait-on fait mon portrait ?

eng: yes, I observed it, I assure you. ~~~ It was not lost on me. ~~~ But still I cannot imagine she would not be persuaded."
fr: >> -- J'ai bien remarque et j'ai apprecie ; mais je ne puis croire qu'elle ne puisse etre persuadee.

eng: Harriet was soon back again, and the proposal almost immediately made; and she had no scruples which could stand many minutes against the earnest pressing of both the others.
fr: Harriet revint au bout de quelques instants : elle ne se fit pas prier longtemps et apres avoir faiblement proteste acquiesca a la proposition de son amie.

eng: Emma wished to go to work directly, and therefore produced the portfolio containing her various attempts at portraits, for not one of them had ever been finished, that they might decide together on the best size for Harriet.
fr: Emma voulut se mettre au travail sans retard et en consequence alla chercher un portefeuille contenant diverses ebauches.

eng: Her many beginnings were displayed.
fr: Aucun des portraits entrepris n'avait ete termine.

eng: Miniatures, half-lengths, whole-lengths, pencil, crayon, and water-colours had been all tried in turn.
fr: Ils chercherent ensemble le procede qui conviendrait le mieux.

eng: She had always wanted to do every thing, and had made more progress both in drawing and music than many might have done with so little labour as she would ever submit to.
fr: Emma avait essaye de tout : miniature, pastel, crayon, aquarelle.

eng: She played and sang;--and drew in almost every style; but steadiness had always been wanting; and in nothing had she approached the degree of excellence which she would have been glad to command, and ought not to have failed of.
fr: Mais la perseverance lui faisait defaut et, malgre ses dons naturels, elle ne reussissait pas a atteindre de degre de perfection qu'elle ambitionnait.

eng: She was not much deceived as to her own skill either as an artist or a musician, but she was not unwilling to have others deceived, or sorry to know her reputation for accomplishment often higher than it deserved.
fr: Sans s'illusionner elle-meme sur ses capacites, elle supportait volontiers que les autres s'y trompassent et n'etait pas fachee que sa reputation surpassat son merite reel.

eng: There was merit in every drawing--in the least finished, perhaps the most; her style was spirited; but had there been much less, or had there been ten times more, the delight and admiration of her two companions would have been the same.
fr: Dans le cas present, la partialite de ses amis etait evidente : la plupart des dessins d'Emma temoignaient en verite de certaines qualites, mais en eussent-ils ete entierement depourvus, l'admiration d'Harriet et de M. Elton n'aurait pas ete moins chaleureuse.

eng: They were both in ecstasies.
fr: Ils etaient tous deux en extase.

eng: A likeness pleases every body; and Miss Woodhouse's performances must be capital.
"No great variety of faces for you," said Emma.
fr: -- Il n'y a pas grande variete, dit Emma.

eng: "I had only my own family to study from. ~~~ There is my father--another of my father--but the idea of sitting for his picture made him so nervous, that I could only take him by stealth; neither of them very like therefore.
fr: Je n'avais que les membres de ma famille comme modeles : voici mon pere, le voici encore une fois, mais cela le rendait si nerveux de poser que j'en etais reduite a dessiner a son insu ; en consequence, la ressemblance est mediocre...

eng: Mrs. Weston again, and again, and again, you see.
fr: Voici Mme Weston sous toutes ses faces !

eng: Dear Mrs. Weston!
always my kindest friend on every occasion.

She would sit whenever I asked her. ~~~ There is my sister; and really quite her own little elegant figure!--and the face not unlike. ~~~ I should have made a good likeness of her, if she would have sat longer, but she was in such a hurry to have me draw her four children that she would not be quiet.
fr: Voici ma soeur : c'est bien sa silhouette elegante et son aimable figure ; j'aurais, je crois, bien reussi ce portrait, mais Isabelle etait tellement preoccupee de me voir commencer celui de ses quatre enfants qu'elle ne tenait pas en place...

eng: Then, here come all my attempts at three of those four children;--there they are, Henry and John and Bella, from one end of the sheet to the other, and any one of them might do for any one of the rest. ~~~ She was so eager to have them drawn that I could not refuse; but there is no making children of three or four years old stand still you know; nor can it be very easy to take any likeness of them, beyond the air and complexion, unless they are coarser featured than any of mama's children ever were.
fr: Enfin voici les croquis des trois aines : Henry, Jean et Bella ; chacun de ces dessins pourrait, du reste, s'appliquer aussi bien a l'un qu'a l'autre ; comme vous pouvez l'imaginer, il n'y a pas moyen de faire tenir tranquilles des enfants de trois et quatre ans ; de plus tous ces petits visages se ressemblent... Voila le quatrieme qui n'etait encore qu'un bebe ; je l'ai dessine pendant qu'il dormait sur le sofa : c'est l'exacte ressemblance de son petit bonnet, car il avait pris soin de dissimuler sa figure pour ma plus grande commodite.

eng: Here is my sketch of the fourth, who was a baby.
fr: Je suis assez fiere de ce portrait du petit Georges !...

eng: I took him as he was sleeping on the sofa, and it is as strong a likeness of his cockade as you would wish to see.
He had nestled down his head most conveniently.
fr: Voici mon dernier ouvrage ; mon beau-frere, M.

eng: That's very like.
I am rather proud of little George.

The corner of the sofa is very good. ~~~ Then here is my last,"--unclosing a pretty sketch of a gentleman in small size, whole-length--"my last and my best--my brother, Mr. John Knightley.--This did not want much of being finished, when I put it away in a pet, and vowed I would never take another likeness.
fr: Jean Knightley, avait consenti a poser ; apres m'etre donne beaucoup de peine, j'etais assez satisfaite du resultat ; tandis que je me preparais a placer les dernieres retouches, Isabelle s'approcha pour donner son avis : << Je vois bien une petite ressemblance, mais je suis forcee de constater que M.

eng: I could not help being provoked; for after all my pains, and when I had really made a very good likeness of it--(Mrs. Weston and I were quite agreed in thinking it _very_ like)--only too handsome--too flattering--but that was a fault on the right side"--after all this, came poor dear Isabella's cold approbation of--"Yes, it was a little like--but to be sure it did not do him justice.
fr: Jean Knightley est beaucoup mieux en realite.

eng: We had had a great deal of trouble in persuading him to sit at all.
fr: >> C'est tout ce qu'elle trouva a dire.

eng: It was made a great favour of; and altogether it was more than I could bear; and so I never would finish it, to have it apologised over as an unfavourable likeness, to every morning visitor in Brunswick Square;--and, as I said, I did then forswear ever drawing any body again.
But for Harriet's sake, or rather for my own, and as there are no husbands and wives in the case _at_ _present_, I will break my resolution now."
fr: J'en eprouvai un veritable depit d'autant plus que le modele etait indiscutablement flatte.

eng: Mr. Elton seemed very properly struck and delighted by the idea, and was repeating, "No husbands and wives in the case at present indeed, as you observe.
Exactly so. ~~~ No husbands and wives," with so interesting a consciousness, that Emma began to consider whether she had not better leave them together at once.
fr: Je m'etais bien promis de ne plus m'exposer a des deboires de ce genre ; neanmoins je suis disposee, en l'honneur d'Harriet, a manquer a mon voeu, puisqu'il n'y a pas, dans le cas present, d'amour-propre conjugal en jeu... pour le moment du moins !

eng: But as she wanted to be drawing, the declaration must wait a little longer.
fr: Apres quelques hesitations, Emma se decida pour un portrait en pied, a l'aquarelle.

eng: She had soon fixed on the size and sort of portrait.
fr: La seance commenca.

eng: It was to be a whole-length in water-colours, like Mr. John Knightley's, and was destined, if she could please herself, to hold a very honourable station over the mantelpiece.
fr: Harriet rougissante et souriante sous l'oeil attentif de l'artiste, reunissait toutes les graces de la jeunesse.

eng: The sitting began; and Harriet, smiling and blushing, and afraid of not keeping her attitude and countenance, presented a very sweet mixture of youthful expression to the steady eyes of the artist.
But there was no doing any thing, with Mr. Elton fidgeting behind her and watching every touch.
fr: Mais Emma sentait qu'elle ne pourrait rien faire tant que M. Elton se tiendrait a ses cotes, observant chaque coup de crayon.

eng: She gave him credit for stationing himself where he might gaze and gaze again without offence; but was really obliged to put an end to it, and request him to place himself elsewhere. ~~~ It then occurred to her to employ him in reading.
fr: Tout d'abord elle ne dit rien pour lui laisser toute latitude de contempler le modele ; au bout de quelques minutes elle fut obligee de mettre un terme a cette agitation et de le prier de s'eloigner.

eng: "If he would be so good as to read to them, it would be a kindness indeed!
fr: Il lui vint ensuite a l'idee de l'occuper a lire.

eng: It would amuse away the difficulties of her part, and lessen the irksomeness of Miss Smith's."
fr: -- Si vous vouliez etre assez aimable pour nous lire a haute voix, je travaillerais plus librement et le temps paraitrait moins long a Mlle Smith.

eng: Mr. Elton was only too happy.
fr: L'interpelle se declara trop heureux de se rendre utile.

eng: Harriet listened, and Emma drew in peace.
fr: Harriet ecoutait et Emma dessinait en paix.

eng: She must allow him to be still frequently coming to look; any thing less would certainly have been too little in a lover; and he was ready at the smallest intermission of the pencil, to jump up and see the progress, and be charmed.--There was no being displeased with such an encourager, for his admiration made him discern a likeness almost before it was possible. ~~~ She could not respect his eye, but his love and his complaisance were unexceptionable.
fr: Elle dut pourtant autoriser M. Elton a venir de temps en temps jeter un coup d'oeil et celui-ci s'extasiait a chaque progres ; c'etait un critique encourageant qui distinguait la ressemblance avant meme que les elements constitutifs en fussent assembles !

eng: The sitting was altogether very satisfactory; she was quite enough pleased with the first day's sketch to wish to go on.
fr: Si Emma tenait en petite estime la competence artistique de M. Elton, elle ne pouvait que se rejouir de son aveuglement d'amoureux.

eng: There was no want of likeness, she had been fortunate in the attitude, and as she meant to throw in a little improvement to the figure, to give a little more height, and considerably more elegance, she had great confidence of its being in every way a pretty drawing at last, and of its filling its destined place with credit to them both--a standing memorial of the beauty of one, the skill of the other, and the friendship of both; with as many other agreeable associations as Mr. Elton's very promising attachment was likely to add.
fr: La seance fut satisfaisante a tous les points de vue : Emma etait assez contente de cette premiere esquisse pour desirer continuer ; il y avait deja un air de ressemblance, l'attitude etait gracieuse et les details heureusement choisis ; elle esperait que ce portrait leur ferait honneur a toutes deux ; il perpetuerait le souvenir de la beaute de l'une, du talent de l'autre et de leur commune amitie ; elle escomptait aussi les associations d'idees accessoires que l'attachement naissant de M. Elton ne manquerait pas d'y ajouter.

eng: Harriet was to sit again the next day; and Mr. Elton, just as he ought, entreated for the permission of attending and reading to them again.
fr: Harriet devait poser le lendemain, et M. Elton ne manqua pas de solliciter l'autorisation d'assister a la seance et de continuer son office de lecteur.

eng: "By all means. ~~~ We shall be most happy to consider you as one of the party."
fr: << Certainement, nous serons heureuses de vous considerer comme un des notres.

eng: The same civilities and courtesies, the same success and satisfaction, took place on the morrow, and accompanied the whole progress of the picture, which was rapid and happy.
fr: >> Le jour suivant, la reunion fut empreinte de la meme cordialite et il en fut de meme jusqu'a l'achevement du portrait qui obtint l'approbation generale.

eng: Every body who saw it was pleased, but Mr. Elton was in continual raptures, and defended it through every criticism.
fr: Quant a M. Elton, son admiration n'avait pas de bornes et il n'admettait aucune critique.

eng: "Miss Woodhouse has given her friend the only beauty she wanted,"--observed Mrs. Weston to him--not in the least suspecting that she was addressing a lover.--"The expression of the eye is most correct, but Miss Smith has not those eyebrows and eyelashes.
fr: << Mlle Woodhouse a dote son amie de la seule beaute qui lui manque >>, dit Mme Weston en s'adressant a M. Elton.

eng: It is the fault of her face that she has them not."
fr: << L'expression de l'oeil est parfaite, mais Mlle Smith n'a pas des sourcils et des cils pareils ; c'est l'unique defaut de son visage.

eng: "Do you think so?"
fr: -- Vous trouvez ?

eng: replied he.
fr: reprit-il.

eng: "I cannot agree with you. ~~~ It appears to me a most perfect resemblance in every feature.
fr: Je ne puis etre de votre avis ; la ressemblance me parait parfaite dans tous ses details.

eng: I never saw such a likeness in my life.
fr: Il faut calculer l'effet de l'ombre.

eng: We must allow for the effect of shade, you know."
"You have made her too tall, Emma," said Mr. Knightley.
fr: -- Vous l'avez faite trop grande, Emma, fit observer M. Knightley.

eng: Emma knew that she had, but would not own it; and Mr. Elton warmly added, "Oh no! ~~~ certainly not too tall; not in the least too tall. ~~~ Consider, she is sitting down--which naturally presents a different--which in short gives exactly the idea--and the proportions must be preserved, you know. ~~~ Proportions, fore-shortening.--Oh no! ~~~ it gives one exactly the idea of such a height as Miss Smith's.
fr: Emma s'en etait rendu compte, mais elle ne voulait pas en convenir, et M. Elton ajouta avec chaleur : -- Bien entendu, la position assise modifie les proportions, mais ce raccourci me suggere exactement l'idee de la taille de Mlle Smith.

eng: Exactly so indeed!" ~~~ "It is very pretty," said Mr. Woodhouse. ~~~ "So prettily done!
fr: -- C'est extremement joli dit M. Woodhouse, et si bien dessine et peint !

eng: Just as your drawings always are, my dear.
fr: Comme tout ce que vous faites, ma chere.

eng: I do not know any body who draws so well as you do.
The only thing I do not thoroughly like is, that she seems to be sitting out of doors, with only a little shawl over her shoulders--and it makes one think she must catch cold."
fr: Il n'y a qu'une chose a laquelle je trouverais a redire : Mlle Smith parait etre assise dehors et elle n'a qu'un petit chale sur les epaules !

eng: "But, my dear papa, it is supposed to be summer; a warm day in summer.
fr: -- Mais mon cher papa, nous sommes supposes etre dans la belle saison, le decor evoque une chaude journee d'ete.

eng: Look at the tree."
fr: Voyez les feuilles de cet arbre !

eng: "But it is never safe to sit out of doors, my dear."
fr: -- Mais ma chere, il n'est jamais prudent de s'asseoir dehors.

eng: "You, sir, may say any thing," cried Mr. Elton, "but I must confess that I regard it as a most happy thought, the placing of Miss Smith out of doors; and the tree is touched with such inimitable spirit! ~~~ Any other situation would have been much less in character.
fr: -- Je m'incline devant votre avis, Monsieur, dit M. Elton, mais il me semble, je dois l'avouer, que c'est une tres heureuse idee d'avoir place Mlle Smith en plein air ; aucun autre cadre ne se fut harmonise aussi parfaitement avec la grace et le naturel du modele.

eng: The naivete of Miss Smith's manners--and altogether--Oh, it is most admirable!
I cannot keep my eyes from it. ~~~ I never saw such a likeness."
fr: Je ne puis voir de defaut a ce portrait ni en detacher mon regard.

eng: The next thing wanted was to get the picture framed; and here were a few difficulties. ~~~ It must be done directly; it must be done in London; the order must go through the hands of some intelligent person whose taste could be depended on; and Isabella, the usual doer of all commissions, must not be applied to, because it was December, and Mr. Woodhouse could not bear the idea of her stirring out of her house in the fogs of December. ~~~ But no sooner was the distress known to Mr. Elton, than it was removed.
fr: Il fallut ensuite songer a faire encadrer l'aquarelle et a ce propos quelques difficultes se presenterent ; Emma desirait que le cadre fut commande... sans retard... a Londres... par l'intermediaire d'une personne intelligente et d'un gout sur ; on ne pouvait songer a avoir recours a Isabelle, car M. Woodhouse n'aurait pu supporter l'idee que sa fille fut obligee de sortir par les brouillards de decembre.

eng: His gallantry was always on the alert. ~~~ "Might he be trusted with the commission, what infinite pleasure should he have in executing it!
fr: Des que M. Elton eut ete mis au courant de la perplexite ou se trouvaient ses amis, il proposa une solution : le jugerait-on digne de faire la commission ?

eng: he could ride to London at any time.
fr: Il aurait un plaisir infini a l'executer.

eng: It was impossible to say how much he should be gratified by being employed on such an errand."
fr: Il lui serait facile de se rendre a Londres a cheval et on ne pouvait savoir a quel point il se sentirait flatte d'une pareille mission.

eng: "He was too good!--she could not endure the thought!--she would not give him such a troublesome office for the world,"--brought on the desired repetition of entreaties and assurances,--and a very few minutes settled the business.
fr: Apres avoir remercie et declare qu'elle ne voudrait a aucun prix lui causer un tel derangement, Emma finit par ceder et accepta le concours de M. Elton ; il fut convenu que ce dernier porterait l'aquarelle a Londres, choisirait le cadre et donnerait les instructions necessaires.

eng: Mr. Elton was to take the drawing to London, chuse the frame, and give the directions; and Emma thought she could so pack it as to ensure its safety without much incommoding him, while he seemed mostly fearful of not being incommoded enough.
fr: Emma lui promit de faire un paquet de petite dimension afin de l'embarrasser le moins possible ; mais M. Elton semblait n'avoir qu'une crainte, c'etait que le colis ne fut pas suffisamment encombrant.

eng: "What a precious deposit!" ~~~ said he with a tender sigh, as he received it.
fr: -- Quel precieux depot, dit-il avec un soupir, quand il le recut.

eng: "This man is almost too gallant to be in love," thought Emma. ~~~ "I should say so, but that I suppose there may be a hundred different ways of being in love.
fr: << Je m'explique mal l'empressement galant dont il fait preuve a mon egard, etant donne les circonstances, pensa Emma, mais il y a sans doute un grand nombre de manieres d'etre amoureux.

eng: He is an excellent young man, and will suit Harriet exactly; it will be an 'Exactly so,' as he says himself; but he does sigh and languish, and study for compliments rather more than I could endure as a principal. ~~~ I come in for a pretty good share as a second.
fr: C'est un excellent jeune homme qui conviendra parfaitement a Harriet ; je trouve seulement qu'il abuse des soupirs et des compliments : pour un personnage de second plan ma part de louanges est excessive.

eng: But it is his gratitude on Harriet's account."
fr: Sans doute, il agit ainsi par reconnaissance.

eng: CHAPTER VII The very day of Mr. Elton's going to London produced a fresh occasion for Emma's services towards her friend.
fr: >> VII Le jour meme du voyage de M. Elton a Londres un evenement se produisit qui fut l'occasion pour Emma de juger de son influence sur Harriet.

eng: Harriet had been at Hartfield, as usual, soon after breakfast; and, after a time, had gone home to return again to dinner: she returned, and sooner than had been talked of, and with an agitated, hurried look, announcing something extraordinary to have happened which she was longing to tell. ~~~ Half a minute brought it all out.
fr: Celle-ci etait venue faire une visite a Hartfield apres dejeuner comme d'habitude ; elle etait ensuite rentree chez elle et devait revenir pour diner ; elle arriva avant l'heure convenue ; son air nerveux et agite indiquait clairement qu'il s'etait passe quelque chose d'extraordinaire dont elle brulait de faire part a son amie.

eng: She had heard, as soon as she got back to Mrs. Goddard's, that Mr. Martin had been there an hour before, and finding she was not at home, nor particularly expected, had left a little parcel for her from one of his sisters, and gone away; and on opening this parcel, she had actually found, besides the two songs which she had lent Elizabeth to copy, a letter to herself; and this letter was from him, from Mr. Martin, and contained a direct proposal of marriage.
fr: A peine assise, elle commenca son recit : << Pendant mon absence, M. Martin est venu me demander ; il a rapporte differents morceaux de musique que j'avais pretes a Elisabeth ; en ouvrant le rouleau j'ai ete tres etonnee d'y trouver une lettre de lui - de M. Martin -- contenant une explicite demande en mariage.

eng: "Who could have thought it?
fr: Qui aurait pu imaginer une chose pareille ?

eng: She was so surprized she did not know what to do. ~~~ Yes, quite a proposal of marriage; and a very good letter, at least she thought so.
fr: La lettre est bien tournee, du moins je le crois ; j'ai l'impression qu'il m'aime beaucoup et je suis tres embarrassee pour repondre ; je me suis hatee de venir vous trouver pour demander avis et conseil.

eng: And he wrote as if he really loved her very much--but she did not know--and so, she was come as fast as she could to ask Miss Woodhouse what she should do.--" Emma was half-ashamed of her friend for seeming so pleased and so doubtful.
fr: >> Emma se sentit honteuse en voyant son amie manifester une satisfaction si evidente.

eng: "Upon my word," she cried, "the young man is determined not to lose any thing for want of asking. ~~~ He will connect himself well if he can."
fr: -- Sur ma parole, dit-elle, ce jeune homme est decide a ne pas laisser echapper l'occasion de se marier avantageusement.

eng: "Will you read the letter?"
fr: -- Voulez-vous lire la lettre ?

eng: cried Harriet.
fr: reprit Harriet.

eng: "Pray do.
I'd rather you would."
Emma was not sorry to be pressed.
fr: Emma ne se fit pas prier.

eng: She read, and was surprized.

The style of the letter was much above her expectation. ~~~ There were not merely no grammatical errors, but as a composition it would not have disgraced a gentleman; the language, though plain, was strong and unaffected, and the sentiments it conveyed very much to the credit of the writer. ~~~ It was short, but expressed good sense, warm attachment, liberality, propriety, even delicacy of feeling.
fr: Elle lut et demeura etonnee : non seulement il n'y avait pas de fautes de grammaire, mais la lettre etait digne d'un homme d'education ; le ton tout en restant simple etait sincere et convaincant et tous les sentiments exprimes faisaient honneur a celui qui l'avait redigee ; Harriet observait attentivement son amie et dit enfin : -- Eh bien, la lettre vous parait-elle bien ?

eng: She paused over it, while Harriet stood anxiously watching for her opinion, with a "Well, well," and was at last forced to add, "Is it a good letter?
fr: -- C'est, ma foi, une lettre fort bien tournee reprit Emma, et je suis portee a croire que ses soeurs ont du y collaborer.

eng: or is it too short?" ~~~ "Yes, indeed, a very good letter," replied Emma rather slowly--"so good a letter, Harriet, that every thing considered, I think one of his sisters must have helped him.
fr: J'imagine difficilement que le jeune homme que j'ai vu causer avec vous l'autre jour puisse, livre a ses propres moyens, s'exprimer avec tant d'elegance.

eng: I can hardly imagine the young man whom I saw talking with you the other day could express himself so well, if left quite to his own powers, and yet it is not the style of a woman; no, certainly, it is too strong and concise; not diffuse enough for a woman.
No doubt he is a sensible man, and I suppose may have a natural talent for--thinks strongly and clearly--and when he takes a pen in hand, his thoughts naturally find proper words.
It is so with some men. ~~~ Yes, I understand the sort of mind.
fr: Pourtant ce n'est pas le style d'une femme : c'est trop concis et vigoureux.

eng: Vigorous, decided, with sentiments to a certain point, not coarse. ~~~ A better written letter, Harriet (returning it,) than I had expected."
fr: Evidemment ce jeune homme a du bon sens ; il pense clairement et quand il prend la plume il trouve les mots appropries.

eng: "Well," said the still waiting Harriet;--"well--and--and what shall I do?"
fr: Elle ajouta, en rendant la lettre : -- Vraiment cette lettre surpasse de beaucoup mon attente.

eng: "What shall you do!
fr: -- Eh bien ?

eng: In what respect?
fr: Eh bien ?

eng: Do you mean with regard to this letter?" ~~~ "Yes."
fr: Que dois-je faire ?

eng: "But what are you in doubt of?
fr: -- A quel point de vue ?

eng: You must answer it of course--and speedily."
fr: Voulez-vous dire relativement a cette lettre ?

eng: "Yes.
fr: -- Oui.

eng: But what shall I say? ~~~ Dear Miss Woodhouse, do advise me."
fr: -- Mais il faut y repondre, bien entendu, sans delai.

eng: "Oh no, no!
fr: -- Que dois-je dire ?

eng: the letter had much better be all your own.
fr: Chere Mlle Woodhouse donnez-moi votre avis.

eng: You will express yourself very properly, I am sure. ~~~ There is no danger of your not being intelligible, which is the first thing. ~~~ Your meaning must be unequivocal; no doubts or demurs: and such expressions of gratitude and concern for the pain you are inflicting as propriety requires, will present themselves unbidden to _your_ mind, I am persuaded.
fr: -- Non, Harriet, ecrivez votre reponse en toute liberte ; l'essentiel est de vous faire clairement comprendre : il ne faut pas d'equivoque, pas de doute, pas de sursis ; quant aux expressions de reconnaissance et de regret pour le desappointement que vous causez elles vous viendront tout naturellement sous la plume.

eng: You need not be prompted to write with the appearance of sorrow for his disappointment."
fr: -- Alors... vous trouvez que je dois refuser, dit Harriet en baissant les yeux.

eng: "You think I ought to refuse him then," said Harriet, looking down.
"Ought to refuse him!
fr: -- Si vous devez refuser !

eng: My dear Harriet, what do you mean?
fr: Ma chere Harriet, que voulez-vous dire ?

eng: Are you in any doubt as to that? ~~~ I thought--but I beg your pardon, perhaps I have been under a mistake. ~~~ I certainly have been misunderstanding you, if you feel in doubt as to the _purport_ of your answer.
fr: Il y a un malentendu entre nous, puisque vous avez un doute sur le sens meme de votre reponse ; je croyais, moi, que vous me consultiez simplement sur la forme et je vous demande pardon de m'etre avancee de la sorte.

eng: I had imagined you were consulting me only as to the wording of it." ~~~ Harriet was silent.
fr: Harriet demeura silencieuse et Emma reprit avec une certaine reserve.

eng: With a little reserve of manner, Emma continued: "You mean to return a favourable answer, I collect."
fr: -- D'apres ce que je comprends, vous comptez donner une reponse favorable.

eng: "No, I do not; that is, I do not mean--What shall I do?
fr: -- Non, je n'ai pas cette intention... Que dois-je faire ?
