fr: Je desire reellement que vous fassiez cette visite ; les Bates y seront extremement sensibles.

eng: He could say no more; and with the hope of Hartfield to reward him, returned with Mrs. Weston to Mrs. Bates's door.
fr: Frank Churchill n'avait plus rien a repondre ; ils se dirigerent de nouveau vers la porte de Mme Bates.

eng: Emma watched them in, and then joined Harriet at the interesting counter,--trying, with all the force of her own mind, to convince her that if she wanted plain muslin it was of no use to look at figured; and that a blue ribbon, be it ever so beautiful, would still never match her yellow pattern.
fr: Emma les regarda entrer et rejoignit ensuite Henriette qui se penchait perplexe sur le comptoir de M. Ford ; elle essaya de persuader a son amie qu'ayant besoin de mousseline unie, il etait parfaitement inutile d'examiner de la mousseline brodee et qu'un ruban bleu, malgre sa beaute, ne pourrait jamais s'appareiller a un echantillon jaune.

eng: At last it was all settled, even to the destination of the parcel.
fr: Cette intervention eut pour resultat de mettre un terme aux pourparlers.

eng: "Should I send it to Mrs. Goddard's, ma'am?"
fr: -- Devrai-je envoyer le paquet chez Mme Goddard ?

eng: asked Mrs.
fr: demanda Mme Ford.
-- Oui... non... chez Mme Goddard... ; seulement ma jupe modele est a Hartfield, envoyez-le a Hartfield, s'il vous plait.

eng: Ford.--"Yes--no--yes, to Mrs. Goddard's.
fr: Mme Goddard, il est vrai, voudra le voir.

eng: Only my pattern gown is at Hartfield.
fr: Pourtant j'aurais besoin du ruban immediatement.

eng: No, you shall send it to Hartfield, if you please.
fr: Ne pourriez-vous pas faire deux paquets, Mme Ford ?

eng: But then, Mrs. Goddard will want to see it.--And I could take the pattern gown home any day.
fr: -- A quoi bon, Henriette, donner a Mme Ford la peine de faire deux paquets ?

eng: But I shall want the ribbon directly--so it had better go to Hartfield--at least the ribbon.
fr: -- Il n'y a pas la moindre difficulte, intervint Mme Ford obligeamment.

eng: You could make it into two parcels, Mrs. Ford, could not you?"
fr: -- Je prefere, somme toute, n'avoir qu'un paquet.

eng: "It is not worth while, Harriet, to give Mrs. Ford the trouble of two parcels."
fr: Donnez-moi votre avis, Mlle Woodhouse. ~~~ Ne vaut-il pas mieux le faire envoyer a Hartfield ?

eng: "No more it is."
fr: -- N'hesitez pas une seconde de plus.

eng: "No trouble in the world, ma'am," said the obliging Mrs. Ford.
fr: A Hartfield, s'il vous plait, Mme Ford.

eng: "Oh! ~~~ but indeed I would much rather have it only in one.
fr: A ce moment des voix se rapprochaient ou plutot une voix et deux dames ; Mme Weston et Mlle Bates entraient dans le magasin.

eng: Then, if you please, you shall send it all to Mrs. Goddard's--I do not know--No, I think, Miss Woodhouse, I may just as well have it sent to Hartfield, and take it home with me at night.
fr: -- Ma chere Mlle Woodhouse, dit cette derniere, j'ai traverse la rue pour vous prier de nous faire la faveur de venir vous asseoir quelques instants a la maison afin de nous donner votre avis sur le nouvel instrument.

eng: What do you advise?"
fr: Vous et Mlle Smith.

eng: "That you do not give another half-second to the subject.
To Hartfield, if you please, Mrs.
fr: Comment allez-vous Mlle Smith ?

eng: Ford." ~~~ "Aye, that will be much best," said Harriet, quite satisfied, "I should not at all like to have it sent to Mrs.
Goddard's."
fr: -- Tres bien, merci.

eng: Voices approached the shop--or rather one voice and two ladies: Mrs. Weston and Miss Bates met them at the door.

"My dear Miss Woodhouse," said the latter, "I am just run across to entreat the favour of you to come and sit down with us a little while, and give us your opinion of our new instrument; you and Miss Smith.
How do you do, Miss Smith?--Very well I thank you.--And I begged Mrs. Weston to come with me, that I might be sure of succeeding."
fr: J'ai supplie Mme Weston de m'accompagner afin d'etre sure de reussir.

eng: "I hope Mrs. Bates and Miss Fairfax are--" "Very well, I am much obliged to you.
fr: -- J'espere que Mme Bates et Mlle Fairfax vont... -- Tres bien, je vous suis bien reconnaissante.

eng: My mother is delightfully well; and Jane caught no cold last night.
fr: Ma mere va parfaitement et Jane n'a pas pris froid hier soir.

eng: How is Mr.
fr: Comment se porte M. Woodhouse ?

eng: Woodhouse?--I am so glad to hear such a good account.
fr: J'ai appris par Mme Weston votre presence ici. ~~~ -- Oh !
alors, ai-je dit, je vais aller la trouver et lui demander d'entrer un instant ; ma mere sera si heureuse de la voir et il y a en ce moment chez nous une reunion si agreable qu'elle ne peut refuser.

eng: Mrs. Weston told me you were here.--Oh!
fr: Tout le monde approuva ma proposition.

eng: then, said I, I must run across, I am sure Miss Woodhouse will allow me just to run across and entreat her to come in; my mother will be so very happy to see her--and now we are such a nice party, she cannot refuse.--'Aye, pray do,' said Mr. Frank Churchill, 'Miss Woodhouse's opinion of the instrument will be worth having.'
fr: << C'est une excellente idee, dit M. Frank Churchill, l'opinion de Mlle Woodhouse sera importante a connaitre.

eng: --But, said I, I shall be more sure of succeeding if one of you will go with me.--'Oh,' said he, 'wait half a minute, till I have finished my job;'--For, would you believe it, Miss Woodhouse, there he is, in the most obliging manner in the world, fastening in the rivet of my mother's spectacles.--The rivet came out, you know, this morning.--So very obliging!--For my mother had no use of her spectacles--could not put them on.
And, by the bye, every body ought to have two pair of spectacles; they should indeed.
fr: >> << Mais, dis-je, je serai plus sure de reussir si l'un de vous m'accompagne.

eng: Jane said so.

fr: dit-il, attendez une demi-minute, je vais avoir termine mon travail.

eng: I meant to take them over to John Saunders the first thing I did, but something or other hindered me all the morning; first one thing, then another, there is no saying what, you know.
fr: >> Car, le croiriez-vous Mlle Woodhouse, il est en ce moment occupe de la facon la plus obligeante du monde a fixer la branche des lunettes de ma mere : la vis etait tombee ce matin.

eng: At one time Patty came to say she thought the kitchen chimney wanted sweeping.
fr: On ne peut etre plus aimable !

eng: Oh, said I, Patty do not come with your bad news to me.
fr: Ma mere ne savait comment faire sans ses lunettes.

eng: Here is the rivet of your mistress's spectacles out.
fr: C'est une lecon : tout le monde devrait avoir deux paires de lunettes.

eng: Then the baked apples came home, Mrs. Wallis sent them by her boy; they are extremely civil and obliging to us, the Wallises, always--I have heard some people say that Mrs. Wallis can be uncivil and give a very rude answer, but we have never known any thing but the greatest attention from them.
fr: J'avais l'intention de les porter des la premiere heure chez John Sanders pour les faire reparer, mais je ne sais trop comment j'ai ete retardee toute la matinee.

eng: And it cannot be for the value of our custom now, for what is our consumption of bread, you know?
fr: A un moment donne, Patty est venue dire que la cheminee de la cuisine avait besoin d'etre ramonee.

eng: Only three of us.--besides dear Jane at present--and she really eats nothing--makes such a shocking breakfast, you would be quite frightened if you saw it.
fr: << Oh ! ~~~ Patty, dis-je ne venez pas me raconter vos mauvaises nouvelles.

eng: I dare not let my mother know how little she eats--so I say one thing and then I say another, and it passes off.
fr: C'est assez que les lunettes de votre maitresse soient deteriorees.

>> Ensuite les pommes au four sont arrivees ; Mme Wallis les a fait porter par son garcon ; les Wallis sont extremement obligeants pour nous ; j'ai entendu des gens dire que Mme Wallis etait capable, a l'occasion, de repondre grossierement ; mais, quant a nous, elle nous a toujours traites avec tous les egards possibles ; ce ne peut pas etre par interet, car notre consommation de pain est insignifiante.

eng: But about the middle of the day she gets hungry, and there is nothing she likes so well as these baked apples, and they are extremely wholesome, for I took the opportunity the other day of asking Mr. Perry; I happened to meet him in the street.
fr: Nous sommes, il est vrai, trois a table, mais, en ce moment, la pauvre Jane n'a aucun appetit ; ma mere serait effrayee si elle savait de quoi se compose le dejeuner de Jane ; aussi pendant le repas, je m'efforce de parler d'une chose et puis d'une autre, et elle ne s'apercoit de rien.

eng: Not that I had any doubt before--I have so often heard Mr. Woodhouse recommend a baked apple.
fr: Vers le milieu de la journee, elle commence a sentir la faim et elle prefere les pommes au four a tout autre mets.
Precisement, ces jours derniers, j'ai eu l'occasion de parler avec M. Perry et il m'a confirme la valeur nutritive de cet aliment.

eng: I believe it is the only way that Mr. Woodhouse thinks the fruit thoroughly wholesome.
fr: J'ai du reste entendu M. Woodhouse recommander une pomme au four ; c'est la seule maniere d'accommoder ce fruit, qu'il preconise.

eng: We have apple-dumplings, however, very often.
fr: Eh bien, avons-nous gagne notre cause ?

eng: Patty makes an excellent apple-dumpling.
fr: Vous allez, j'espere, nous accompagner.

eng: Well, Mrs. Weston, you have prevailed, I hope, and these ladies will oblige us."
fr: -- Je serai tres heureux de presenter mes hommages a Mme Bates, repondit Emma.

eng: Emma would be "very happy to wait on Mrs. Bates, &c.," and they did at last move out of the shop, with no farther delay from Miss Bates than, "How do you do, Mrs. Ford?
fr: Elles quitterent finalement le magasin non sans que Mlle Bates eut ajoute : -- Comment allez-vous, Mme Ford ?

eng: I beg your pardon. ~~~ I did not see you before.
fr: Excusez-moi, je ne vous avais pas apercue.

eng: I hear you have a charming collection of new ribbons from town.
fr: Vous avez, parait-il, recu de la ville un charmant assortiment de rubans.

eng: Jane came back delighted yesterday.
fr: Jane est revenue enchantee hier soir.

eng: Thank ye, the gloves do very well--only a little too large about the wrist; but Jane is taking them in."
fr: Je vous remercie, les gants vont parfaitement ; un peu larges seulement autour du poignet et Jane est en train de les arranger.

eng: "What was I talking of?" ~~~ said she, beginning again when they were all in the street.
fr: Des qu'elles furent dans la rue, Mlle Bates reprit : -- Qu'est-ce que je disais ?

eng: Emma wondered on what, of all the medley, she would fix. ~~~ "I declare I cannot recollect what I was talking of.--Oh! ~~~ my mother's spectacles.
fr: Emma se demanda comment la bonne demoiselle parviendrait a faire un choix dans cette inextricable confusion.

eng: So very obliging of Mr. Frank Churchill!
'Oh!'
fr: -- Ah !

eng: said he, 'I do think I can fasten the rivet; I like a job of this kind excessively.'
--Which you know shewed him to be so very....
fr: oui, je parlais des lunettes de ma mere !

eng: Indeed I must say that, much as I had heard of him before and much as I had expected, he very far exceeds any thing....
I do congratulate you, Mrs. Weston, most warmly.
He seems every thing the fondest parent could.... ~~~ 'Oh!'
fr: M. Frank Churchill fit preuve d'une extreme obligeance !

eng: said he, 'I can fasten the rivet. ~~~ I like a job of that sort excessively.' ~~~ I never shall forget his manner.
fr: << Je crois, dit-il, que je pourrais remettre cette vis ; j'aime beaucoup ce genre de travail.

eng: And when I brought out the baked apples from the closet, and hoped our friends would be so very obliging as to take some, 'Oh!'
fr: >> Malgre tout le bien que j'avais entendu dire de lui, la realite a de beaucoup depasse mon attente.

eng: said he directly, 'there is nothing in the way of fruit half so good, and these are the finest-looking home-baked apples I ever saw in my life.'
fr: Je vous felicite bien sincerement, Mme Weston ; il semble vraiment etre le plus affectueux des parents...

eng: That, you know, was so very.... And I am sure, by his manner, it was no compliment.
fr: Je n'oublierai jamais sa maniere d'agir relativement aux lunettes.

eng: Indeed they are very delightful apples, and Mrs. Wallis does them full justice--only we do not have them baked more than twice, and Mr. Woodhouse made us promise to have them done three times--but Miss Woodhouse will be so good as not to mention it.
fr: Quand j'ai apporte les pommes avec l'espoir d'en faire accepter une a nos amis : << Ces pommes, dit-il immediatement sont les plus belles pommes cuites au four que j'aie vues de ma vie >>.

eng: The apples themselves are the very finest sort for baking, beyond a doubt; all from Donwell--some of Mr. Knightley's most liberal supply.
fr: Ce sont en effet des pommes exquises et Mme Wallis en tire tout le parti possible ; elle ne les met au four que deux fois ; M. Woodhouse nous avaient engages a les faire passer trois fois au feu, aussi Mlle Woodhouse sera assez bonne pour ne pas en parler.

eng: He sends us a sack every year; and certainly there never was such a keeping apple anywhere as one of his trees--I believe there is two of them.
fr: Quant aux pommes, elles sont de la meilleure espece pour cuire : toutes proviennent de Donwell ; M. Knightley nous en envoie un sac tous les ans.

eng: My mother says the orchard was always famous in her younger days.
fr: Ma mere dit que le verger de Donwell a toujours ete renomme.

eng: But I was really quite shocked the other day--for Mr. Knightley called one morning, and Jane was eating these apples, and we talked about them and said how much she enjoyed them, and he asked whether we were not got to the end of our stock.
fr: Mais l'autre jour j'ai ete vraiment confuse : M. Knightley est venu nous voir un matin et precisement Jane etait en train de manger des pommes ; nous lui dimes combien nous les trouvions excellentes et il nous demanda si nous etions arrivees au bout de notre provision : << Je suis sur, ajouta-t-il, que vous ne devez plus en avoir et je vous en enverrai d'autres ; j'en ai beaucoup trop et elles vont pourrir.

eng: 'I am sure you must be,' said he, 'and I will send you another supply; for I have a great many more than I can ever use.
fr: >> Je l'ai prie de n'en rien faire ; il nous en restait a peine une demi-douzaine et je n'ai pu dire le contraire.

eng: William Larkins let me keep a larger quantity than usual this year.

I will send you some more, before they get good for nothing.' ~~~ So I begged he would not--for really as to ours being gone, I could not absolutely say that we had a great many left--it was but half a dozen indeed; but they should be all kept for Jane; and I could not at all bear that he should be sending us more, so liberal as he had been already; and Jane said the same.
fr: Apres son depart, Jane me querella presque - je ne devrais pas employer ce mot, car nous n'avons jamais eu une discussion de notre vie - mais elle etait tout a fait desesperee que j'eusse avoue la verite ; j'aurais du, parait-il, laisser entendre qu'il y en avait un grand nombre.

eng: And when he was gone, she almost quarrelled with me--No, I should not say quarrelled, for we never had a quarrel in our lives; but she was quite distressed that I had owned the apples were so nearly gone; she wished I had made him believe we had a great many left.
fr: << Oh !

eng: Oh, said I, my dear, I did say as much as I could.
fr: dis-je, ma chere, j'ai fait ce que j'ai pu >>.

eng: However, the very same evening William Larkins came over with a large basket of apples, the same sort of apples, a bushel at least, and I was very much obliged, and went down and spoke to William Larkins and said every thing, as you may suppose.
fr: Le meme soir, William Larkins arriva avec un enorme panier de pommes ; je suis descendue pour lui parler et j'ai dit tout ce qu'il etait possible de dire, comme vous pouvez bien le supposer.

eng: William Larkins is such an old acquaintance!
fr: William Larkins est une si vieille connaissance !

eng: I am always glad to see him.
fr: Je suis toujours heureuse de le voir.

eng: But, however, I found afterwards from Patty, that William said it was all the apples of _that_ sort his master had; he had brought them all--and now his master had not one left to bake or boil.
fr: J'ai appris ensuite la verite par Patty : William lui confia qu'il n'y avait plus dans le fruitier des pommes de cette espece.

eng: William did not seem to mind it himself, he was so pleased to think his master had sold so many; for William, you know, thinks more of his master's profit than any thing; but Mrs. Hodges, he said, was quite displeased at their being all sent away.
She could not bear that her master should not be able to have another apple-tart this spring.
fr: Mme Hodge etait tres mecontente ; elle ne pouvait pas supporter l'idee que M. Knightley fut prive dorenavant de tartes aux pommes.

eng: He told Patty this, but bid her not mind it, and be sure not to say any thing to us about it, for Mrs. Hodges _would_ be cross sometimes, and as long as so many sacks were sold, it did not signify who ate the remainder. ~~~ And so Patty told me, and I was excessively shocked indeed!
fr: Il recommanda bien a Patty de ne repeter ces paroles a personne et particulierement a nous : preoccupe avant tout des interets de son maitre, il attachait peu d'importance aux acces de mauvaise humeur de Mme Hodges, du moment que le stock entier de pommes avait ete vendu.

eng: I would not have Mr. Knightley know any thing about it for the world!
fr: Pour rien au monde je n'aurais voulu que cette indiscretion arrivat aux oreilles de M. Knightley.

eng: He would be so very....
fr: Il aurait ete si...

eng: I wanted to keep it from Jane's knowledge; but, unluckily, I had mentioned it before I was aware."
fr: Je voulais meme la cacher a Jane, mais, par malheur, j'y ai fait allusion involontairement.

eng: Miss Bates had just done as Patty opened the door; and her visitors walked upstairs without having any regular narration to attend to, pursued only by the sounds of her desultory good-will.
fr: Mlle Bates finissait de parler quand Patty ouvrit la porte ; les visiteuses gravirent l'escalier, non sans etre accablees de recommandations.

eng: "Pray take care, Mrs. Weston, there is a step at the turning.
fr: -- Je vous en prie, Mme Weston, faites attention, il y a une marche au tournant.

eng: Pray take care, Miss Woodhouse, ours is rather a dark staircase--rather darker and narrower than one could wish.
Miss Smith, pray take care.
Miss Woodhouse, I am quite concerned, I am sure you hit your foot.
fr: Mefiez-vous, Mlle Woodhouse, notre escalier est si etroit !

eng: Miss Smith, the step at the turning."
fr: Mlle Smith, regardez bien ou vous mettez le pied.

eng: CHAPTER X The appearance of the little sitting-room as they entered, was tranquillity itself; Mrs. Bates, deprived of her usual employment, slumbering on one side of the fire, Frank Churchill, at a table near her, most deedily occupied about her spectacles, and Jane Fairfax, standing with her back to them, intent on her pianoforte.
fr: Mlle Woodhouse, je suis sure que vous vous etes cognee... XXVIII Une absolue tranquillite regnait dans le petit salon ou les quatre dames penetrerent : Mme Bates, privee de son occupation habituelle, sommeillait d'un cote de la cheminee ; Frank Churchill, assis a une table, etait profondement absorbe dans la reparation des lunettes et Jane Fairfax, leur tournant le dos, se tenait aupres du piano.

eng: Busy as he was, however, the young man was yet able to shew a most happy countenance on seeing Emma again.
fr: Malgre ses occupations, le jeune homme manifesta sa satisfaction de revoir Emma.

eng: "This is a pleasure," said he, in rather a low voice, "coming at least ten minutes earlier than I had calculated.
fr: << Voici un plaisir, dit-il d'une voix un peu basse, qui m'echoit dix minutes plus tot que je ne m'y attendais !

eng: You find me trying to be useful; tell me if you think I shall succeed."
fr: Vous me voyez en train d'essayer de me rendre utile.

eng: "What!"
fr: -- Quoi !

eng: said Mrs. Weston, "have not you finished it yet?
fr: dit Mme Weston, n'avez-vous pas encore termine ?

eng: you would not earn a very good livelihood as a working silversmith at this rate."
fr: Vous ne gagneriez pas facilement votre vie comme bijoutier ! ~~~ -- Je n'ai pas travaille sans interruption, reprit-il.

eng: "I have not been working uninterruptedly," he replied, "I have been assisting Miss Fairfax in trying to make her instrument stand steadily, it was not quite firm; an unevenness in the floor, I believe.
fr: J'ai aide Mlle Fairfax a assurer l'equilibre de son piano ; il n'etait pas bien d'accord, sans doute a cause d'une difference de niveau dans le parquet ; nous avons cale un des pieds avec du papier.

eng: You see we have been wedging one leg with paper. ~~~ This was very kind of you to be persuaded to come. ~~~ I was almost afraid you would be hurrying home."
fr: C'est bien aimable de votre part, Mademoiselle Woodhouse, de vous etre laissee persuader ; je craignais que vous ne fussiez rentree immediatement.

eng: He contrived that she should be seated by him; and was sufficiently employed in looking out the best baked apple for her, and trying to make her help or advise him in his work, till Jane Fairfax was quite ready to sit down to the pianoforte again.
fr: Il s'arrangea a ce qu'Emma fut assise aupres de lui ; s'occupa de chercher pour elle les meilleures pommes, essaya de lui faire donner son avis sur le travail qu'il poursuivait.

eng: That she was not immediately ready, Emma did suspect to arise from the state of her nerves; she had not yet possessed the instrument long enough to touch it without emotion; she must reason herself into the power of performance; and Emma could not but pity such feelings, whatever their origin, and could not but resolve never to expose them to her neighbour again.
fr: Au bout de cinq minutes, Jane Fairfax s'installa de nouveau au piano. ~~~ Emma attribua a l'etat des nerfs et au trouble de Jane la lenteur des preparatifs.

eng: At last Jane began, and though the first bars were feebly given, the powers of the instrument were gradually done full justice to.
fr: A la fin Jane commenca : les premiers accorda furent attaques avec mollesse, mais peu a peu l'instrument fut mis en pleine valeur.

eng: Mrs. Weston had been delighted before, and was delighted again; Emma joined her in all her praise; and the pianoforte, with every proper discrimination, was pronounced to be altogether of the highest promise.
fr: Mme Weston avait ete enchantee auparavant et elle ne le fut pas moins cette fois ; Emma joignit ses eloges a ceux de son amie et le piano fut proclame absolument parfait.

eng: "Whoever Colonel Campbell might employ," said Frank Churchill, with a smile at Emma, "the person has not chosen ill.
fr: -- Quel qu'ait ete le mandataire du colonel Campbell, dit Frank Churchill, avec un sourire a l'adresse d'Emma, cette personne n'a pas mal choisi.

eng: I heard a good deal of Colonel Campbell's taste at Weymouth; and the softness of the upper notes I am sure is exactly what he and _all_ _that_ _party_ would particularly prize.
fr: Je me suis bien rendu compte a Weymouth des gouts du colonel Campbell ; la douceur des notes hautes est precisement la qualite que lui et tout ce clan prisaient par-dessus tout.

eng: I dare say, Miss Fairfax, that he either gave his friend very minute directions, or wrote to Broadwood himself. ~~~ Do not you think so?" ~~~ Jane did not look round.
fr: Il a du donner a son ami des instructions tres precises ou ecrire lui-meme a Broadwood, Ne le pensez-vous pas, Mlle Fairfax ?

eng: She was not obliged to hear. ~~~ Mrs. Weston had been speaking to her at the same moment.
fr: Jane ne se retourna pas ; elle n'etait pas forcee d'avoir entendu, Mme Weston lui ayant parle au meme instant.

eng: "It is not fair," said Emma, in a whisper; "mine was a random guess.
fr: -- Ce n'est pas loyal, dit Emma a mi-voix, ma supposition etait toute gratuite.

eng: Do not distress her."
fr: Ne la tourmentez pas.

eng: He shook his head with a smile, and looked as if he had very little doubt and very little mercy.
fr: Il secoua la tete en souriant et ne parut nourrir ni doute ni pitie.

eng: Soon afterwards he began again, "How much your friends in Ireland must be enjoying your pleasure on this occasion, Miss Fairfax.
fr: Il reprit peu apres : -- Combien vos amis d'Irlande doivent en ce moment se rejouir du plaisir qu'ils vous ont procure, Mlle Fairfax.

eng: I dare say they often think of you, and wonder which will be the day, the precise day of the instrument's coming to hand.
fr: J'imagine qu'ils pensent souvent a vous et cherchent a deviner le jour precis de l'arrivee du piano.

eng: Do you imagine Colonel Campbell knows the business to be going forward just at this time?--Do you imagine it to be the consequence of an immediate commission from him, or that he may have sent only a general direction, an order indefinite as to time, to depend upon contingencies and conveniences?" ~~~ He paused.
fr: -- Jusqu'a ce que j'aie recu une lettre du colonel Campbell, repondit Jane, d'une voix contenue, je ne puis faire aucune conjecture raisonnable ; c'est a peine si j'ose emettre des suppositions.

eng: She could not but hear; she could not avoid answering, "Till I have a letter from Colonel Campbell," said she, in a voice of forced calmness, "I can imagine nothing with any confidence.
fr: -- Pour ma part je voudrais bien etre a meme de prevoir dans combien de temps j'aurai reussi a fixer cette vis !

eng: It must be all conjecture."
fr: Que peut-on dire de sense, Mademoiselle Woodhouse, quand on travaille ?

eng: "Conjecture--aye, sometimes one conjectures right, and sometimes one conjectures wrong.
fr: Les veritables ouvriers, je suppose, restent silencieux, mais nous autres amateurs... Voila, c'est fait.

eng: I wish I could conjecture how soon I shall make this rivet quite firm.
fr: J'ai le plaisir, Madame, ajouta-t-il en s'adressant a Mme Bates, de vous rendre vos lunettes reparees pour un temps.

eng: What nonsense one talks, Miss Woodhouse, when hard at work, if one talks at all;--your real workmen, I suppose, hold their tongues; but we gentlemen labourers if we get hold of a word--Miss Fairfax said something about conjecturing. ~~~ There, it is done.
fr: Il fut remercie avec chaleur par la mere et la fille ; pour echapper aux actions de graces de cette derniere, il se refugia pres du piano ou Mlle Fairfax etait toujours assise et la pria de jouer encore.

eng: I have the pleasure, madam, (to Mrs. Bates,) of restoring your spectacles, healed for the present."
fr: -- Si vous voulez etre tres bonne, dit-il, ce sera une des valses d'hier soir.

eng: He was very warmly thanked both by mother and daughter; to escape a little from the latter, he went to the pianoforte, and begged Miss Fairfax, who was still sitting at it, to play something more.
fr: Vous n'avez pas paru prendre a la danse autant de plaisir que moi ; vous etiez sans doute fatiguee.

eng: "If you are very kind," said he, "it will be one of the waltzes we danced last night;--let me live them over again. ~~~ You did not enjoy them as I did; you appeared tired the whole time.
fr: Je vous soupconne de vous etre rejouie de la fin prematuree de la sauterie, mais moi j'aurais donne un monde pour la prolonger d'une demi-heure.

eng: I believe you were glad we danced no longer; but I would have given worlds--all the worlds one ever has to give--for another half-hour." ~~~ She played.
fr: Quand elle eut termine, il reprit : -- Quelle joie, de reentendre un air auquel un bonheur est associe.

eng: "What felicity it is to hear a tune again which _has_ made one happy!--If I mistake not that was danced at Weymouth."
fr: Si je ne me trompe, nous avons danse a Weymouth cette meme valse ?

eng: She looked up at him for a moment, coloured deeply, and played something else.
fr: Elle leva les yeux vers lui, rougit et se remit a jouer.

eng: He took some music from a chair near the pianoforte, and turning to Emma, said, "Here is something quite new to me.
fr: Il prit sur la chaise qui se trouvait pres du piano plusieurs morceaux de musique et, se tournant vers Emma, il dit : -- Connaissez-vous cet auteur : Cramer ?

eng: Do you know it?--Cramer.--And here are a new set of Irish melodies.
fr: Voici une recente serie de melodies irlandaises : elles ont ete envoyees avec le piano.

eng: That, from such a quarter, one might expect.
fr: Rien d'etonnant venant d'un tel milieu.

eng: This was all sent with the instrument.
fr: C'est une aimable pensee du colonel Campbell, n'est-ce pas ?

eng: Very thoughtful of Colonel Campbell, was not it?--He knew Miss Fairfax could have no music here.
fr: Il savait que Mlle Fairfax ne pouvait pas se procurer de musique ici.

eng: I honour that part of the attention particularly; it shews it to have been so thoroughly from the heart.
fr: Je tiens pour particulierement touchante cette partie du present ; rien n'a ete fait vite, rien incompletement.

eng: Nothing hastily done; nothing incomplete. ~~~ True affection only could have prompted it."
fr: La veritable affection est seule capable de trouver des attentions aussi delicates.

eng: Emma wished he would be less pointed, yet could not help being amused; and when on glancing her eye towards Jane Fairfax she caught the remains of a smile, when she saw that with all the deep blush of consciousness, there had been a smile of secret delight, she had less scruple in the amusement, and much less compunction with respect to her.--This amiable, upright, perfect Jane Fairfax was apparently cherishing very reprehensible feelings.
fr: Emma jeta un regard a la derobee vers Jane Fairfax et surprit la trace d'un sourire : la rougeur cachait mal les marques d'une joie interieure. ~~~ A la suite de cette constatation, les scrupules et la commiseration d'Emma s'evanouirent.

eng: He brought all the music to her, and they looked it over together.--Emma took the opportunity of whispering, "You speak too plain. ~~~ She must understand you."
fr: Elle se pencha pour examiner la musique avec son voisin et profita de l'occasion pour murmurer : -- Vous parlez trop clairement : elle ne peut faire autrement que de vous comprendre.

eng: "I hope she does.
fr: -- Je l'espere bien.

eng: I would have her understand me.
fr: Je desire qu'elle me comprenne.

eng: I am not in the least ashamed of my meaning."
fr: Je n'ai nulle honte de ce que je pense.

eng: "But really, I am half ashamed, and wish I had never taken up the idea."
fr: -- Mais moi j'en ai et je voudrais ne vous avoir jamais fait part de mon soupcon.

eng: "I am very glad you did, and that you communicated it to me.
fr: -- Je suis bien content au contraire d'avoir ete eclaire.

eng: I have now a key to all her odd looks and ways.
fr: J'ai maintenant une cle pour expliquer la bizarrerie de ses airs et de ses manieres.

eng: Leave shame to her. ~~~ If she does wrong, she ought to feel it."
fr: Si elle nourrit des sentiments reprehensibles, il convient qu'elle en souffre.

eng: "She is not entirely without it, I think."
fr: -- Je ne la crois pas absolument innocente.

eng: "I do not see much sign of it.
fr: -- Je ne distingue pas bien les symptomes.

eng: She is playing _Robin_ _Adair_ at this moment--_his_ favourite."
fr: Elle joue en ce moment Robin Adair, le morceau favori de la personne en question.

eng: Shortly afterwards Miss Bates, passing near the window, descried Mr. Knightley on horse-back not far off.
fr: Peu apres, Mlle Bates qui se tenait pres de la fenetre apercut M. Knightley qui passait a cheval.

eng: "Mr. Knightley I declare!--I must speak to him if possible, just to thank him.
fr: -- C'est bien M. Knightley ! ~~~ Je vais essayer de lui parler pour le remercier.

eng: I will not open the window here; it would give you all cold; but I can go into my mother's room you know.
fr: Je n'ouvrirai pas cette fenetre car vous auriez tous froid, mais je puis aller dans la chambre de ma mere.

eng: I dare say he will come in when he knows who is here.
fr: Je vais lui dire que nous avons des visiteurs.

eng: Quite delightful to have you all meet so!--Our little room so honoured!"
fr: C'est delicieux de vous avoir tous ensemble. ~~~ Quel honneur pour notre petit salon.

eng: She was in the adjoining chamber while she still spoke, and opening the casement there, immediately called Mr. Knightley's attention, and every syllable of their conversation was as distinctly heard by the others, as if it had passed within the same apartment.
fr: Elle se dirigea immediatement vers la piece voisine, et attira l'attention de M. Knightley. ~~~ La porte etant restee ouverte, chaque syllabe de leur conversation etait entendue distinctement par tous les assistants.

eng: "How d' ye do?--how d'ye do?--Very well, I thank you.
fr: -- Comment allez-vous ?

eng: So obliged to you for the carriage last night.
fr: commenca Mlle Bates.

eng: We were just in time; my mother just ready for us.
fr: Je vous remercie mille fois pour la voiture.

eng: Pray come in; do come in. ~~~ You will find some friends here."
fr: Nous sommes rentrees juste a temps ; ma mere nous attendait.

eng: So began Miss Bates; and Mr. Knightley seemed determined to be heard in his turn, for most resolutely and commandingly did he say, "How is your niece, Miss Bates?--I want to inquire after you all, but particularly your niece.
fr: Je vous en prie, entrez ; vous trouverez quelques amis : M. Knightley dit d'une voix autoritaire : -- Comment va votre niece, mademoiselle Bates ?

eng: How is Miss Fairfax?--I hope she caught no cold last night.
How is she to-day? ~~~ Tell me how Miss Fairfax is."
fr: J'espere qu'elle n'a pas pris froid hier soir ?

eng: And Miss Bates was obliged to give a direct answer before he would hear her in any thing else.
fr: Mlle Bates fut forcee de donner une reponse directe avant de pouvoir se lancer dans une nouvelle dissertation.

eng: The listeners were amused; and Mrs. Weston gave Emma a look of particular meaning. ~~~ But Emma still shook her head in steady scepticism.
fr: Les auditeurs s'amusaient ; Mme Weston regarda Emma d'un air entendu, mais celle-ci secoua la tete avec scepticisme.

eng: "So obliged to you!--so very much obliged to you for the carriage," resumed Miss Bates.
fr: -- Je vous suis si obligee pour la voiture, reprit Mlle Bates.

eng: He cut her short with, "I am going to Kingston.
fr: Il l'interrompit en disant : -- Je vais a Kinston.

eng: Can I do any thing for you?"
fr: Puis-je faire quelque chose pour vous ?

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: dear, Kingston--are you?--Mrs.
fr: vraiment a Kinston ?

eng: Cole was saying the other day she wanted something from Kingston."
fr: Mme Cole disait l'autre jour qu'elle avait une commission pour Kinston.

eng: "Mrs. Cole has servants to send.
fr: -- Mme Cole a des domestiques a sa disposition, mais je serai content de vous etre utile.

eng: Can I do any thing for _you_?" ~~~ "No, I thank you.
fr: -- Je vous remercie, nous n'avons besoin de rien, mais entrez donc.

eng: But do come in.
fr: Devinez qui est ici ?

eng: Who do you think is here?--Miss Woodhouse and Miss Smith; so kind as to call to hear the new pianoforte.
fr: Mlle Woodhouse et Mlle Smith, venues pour juger le nouveau piano ; mettez votre cheval a la Couronne et venez nous rejoindre.

eng: Do put up your horse at the Crown, and come in."
fr: -- Eh bien, dit-il, peut-etre... pour quelques instants.

eng: "Well," said he, in a deliberating manner, "for five minutes, perhaps."
fr: -- Et il y a aussi Mme Weston et M. Frank Churchill ! ~~~ C'est delicieux : tant d'amis !

eng: "And here is Mrs. Weston and Mr. Frank Churchill too!--Quite delightful; so many friends!"
fr: -- Reflexion faite, ce sera pour une autre fois ; je ne pourrais rester que deux minutes.

eng: "No, not now, I thank you.
fr: Je suis en retard.

eng: I could not stay two minutes.
fr: -- Je vous en prie, ils seront si heureux de vous voir.

eng: I must get on to Kingston as fast as I can."
fr: -- Non ; votre salon est deja plein de monde ; Je reviendrai un autre jour.

eng: "Oh! ~~~ do come in.
fr: -- Comme il vous plaira !

eng: They will be so very happy to see you."
fr: Quelle charmante soiree nous avons passee hier soir !

eng: "No, no; your room is full enough. ~~~ I will call another day, and hear the pianoforte."
fr: Avez-vous admire la facon de danser de Mlle Woodhouse et de M. Frank Churchill ?

eng: "Well, I am so sorry!--Oh!
fr: Je n'ai jamais rien vu de pareil.

eng: Mr. Knightley, what a delightful party last night; how extremely pleasant.--Did you ever see such dancing?--Was not it delightful?--Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill; I never saw any thing equal to it."
"Oh! ~~~ very delightful indeed; I can say nothing less, for I suppose Miss Woodhouse and Mr. Frank Churchill are hearing every thing that passes.
fr: -- Tout a fait delicieux en effet ; il me serait, du reste, difficile de ne pas en convenir, car je suppose que Mlle Woodhouse et M. Frank Churchill sont a portee de la voix !

eng: And (raising his voice still more) I do not see why Miss Fairfax should not be mentioned too.
fr: Mais il n'y a pas d'inconvenient a parler aussi des autres.

eng: I think Miss Fairfax dances very well; and Mrs. Weston is the very best country-dance player, without exception, in England.
fr: A mon avis, Mlle Fairfax danse avec une extreme elegance et je considere Mme Weston comme la plus parfaite executante de musique de danse qui soit en Angleterre !

eng: Now, if your friends have any gratitude, they will say something pretty loud about you and me in return; but I cannot stay to hear it."
fr: Maintenant, si vos amis ont la moindre gratitude, ils feront quelques remarques obligeantes sur notre compte ; je regrette de ne pouvoir rester pour les entendre.

eng: "Oh!
fr: -- Oh !

eng: Mr. Knightley, one moment more; something of consequence--so shocked!--Jane and I are both so shocked about the apples!"
fr: M. Knightley, encore un moment ! ~~~ J'ai quelque chose d'important a vous dire : Jane et moi nous sommes toutes deux si confuses a propos des pommes !

eng: "What is the matter now?"
fr: -- Pourquoi donc ?

eng: "To think of your sending us all your store apples.
fr: -- Est-il possible que vous nous ayez envoye toute votre reserve de pommes !

eng: You said you had a great many, and now you have not one left. ~~~ We really are so shocked!
fr: Vous en aviez encore beaucoup, disiez-vous, et en verite il ne vous en reste pas une.

eng: Mrs. Hodges may well be angry.
fr: Mme Hodges a bien raison d'etre irritee.

eng: William Larkins mentioned it here.
fr: William Larkins nous a tout raconte.

eng: You should not have done it, indeed you should not.
fr: Vous n'auriez pas du agir ainsi.

eng: Ah!
fr: Ah !

eng: he is off.
fr: le voila parti !

eng: He never can bear to be thanked.
fr: Eh bien, ajouta-t-elle en rentrant dans le salon, je n'ai pas reussi.

eng: But I thought he would have staid now, and it would have been a pity not to have mentioned.... Well, (returning to the room,) I have not been able to succeed.
Mr. Knightley cannot stop.
fr: M. Knightley est trop presse pour s'arreter.

eng: He is going to Kingston.
fr: Il va a Kinston.

eng: He asked me if he could do any thing...." "Yes," said Jane, "we heard his kind offers, we heard every thing." ~~~ "Oh!
fr: Il m'a demande s'il pouvait faire quelque chose pour... -- Oui, dit Jane, nous avons entendu ses aimables offres, nous avons tout entendu.

eng: yes, my dear, I dare say you might, because you know, the door was open, and the window was open, and Mr. Knightley spoke loud.
fr: -- Je n'en suis pas etonnee, ma chere, la porte est restee ouverte et M. Knightley parlait tout haut.

eng: You must have heard every thing to be sure.
fr: << Puis-je faire quelque chose pour vous a Kinston ?

eng: 'Can I do any thing for you at Kingston?'
fr: >> m'a-t-il dit.

eng: said he; so I just mentioned.... Oh!
fr: J'en ai profite pour faire allusion a... Oh !

eng: Miss Woodhouse, must you be going?--You seem but just come--so very obliging of you."
fr: Mlle Woodhouse, est-ce qu'il faut que vous partiez ?

eng: Emma found it really time to be at home; the visit had already lasted long; and on examining watches, so much of the morning was perceived to be gone, that Mrs. Weston and her companion taking leave also, could allow themselves only to walk with the two young ladies to Hartfield gates, before they set off for Randalls.
CHAPTER XI It may be possible to do without dancing entirely.
fr: Il me semble que vous arrivez seulement. ~~~ Comme vous etes aimable !

eng: Instances have been known of young people passing many, many months successively, without being at any ball of any description, and no material injury accrue either to body or mind;--but when a beginning is made--when the felicities of rapid motion have once been, though slightly, felt--it must be a very heavy set that does not ask for more.
fr: En examinant les montres, on s'apercut qu'une grande partie de l'apres-midi s'etait ecoulee, Mme Weston et son beau-fils, apres avoir pris conge, a leur tour, accompagnerent les deux jeunes filles jusqu'a la grille d'Hartfield et se haterent de rentrer a Randalls.

eng: Frank Churchill had danced once at Highbury, and longed to dance again; and the last half-hour of an evening which Mr. Woodhouse was persuaded to spend with his daughter at Randalls, was passed by the two young people in schemes on the subject.
fr: XXIX Il est possible de vivre sans danser : on a vu des jeunes gens ne pas aller au bal pendant plusieurs mois de suite et ne s'en ressentir ni au physique ni au moral ; mais une fois le premier pas fait, une fois les delices du mouvement rapide entrevues, il faut etre d'une essence bien grossiere pour ne pas desirer continuer.

eng: Frank's was the first idea; and his the greatest zeal in pursuing it; for the lady was the best judge of the difficulties, and the most solicitous for accommodation and appearance.
fr: Frank Churchill avait danse un soir a Highbury et brulait de recommencer.

eng: But still she had inclination enough for shewing people again how delightfully Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Woodhouse danced--for doing that in which she need not blush to compare herself with Jane Fairfax--and even for simple dancing itself, without any of the wicked aids of vanity--to assist him first in pacing out the room they were in to see what it could be made to hold--and then in taking the dimensions of the other parlour, in the hope of discovering, in spite of all that Mr. Weston could say of their exactly equal size, that it was a little the largest.

His first proposition and request, that the dance begun at Mr. Cole's should be finished there--that the same party should be collected, and the same musician engaged, met with the readiest acquiescence.
fr: Il avait reussi a gagner son pere et sa belle-mere a ses idees et un plan de soiree dansante fut elabore, puis soumis a l'approbation de M. et de Mlle Woodhouse au cours d'une visite a Randalls.

eng: Mr. Weston entered into the idea with thorough enjoyment, and Mrs. Weston most willingly undertook to play as long as they could wish to dance; and the interesting employment had followed, of reckoning up exactly who there would be, and portioning out the indispensable division of space to every couple.
fr: Emma voyait les difficultes materielles du projet, mais en principe elle y etait tout acquise et ne menagea pas son concours a Frank Churchill : ils mesurerent d'abord la chambre ou ils se trouvaient et persisterent ensuite a vouloir prendre les dimensions du salon contigu, malgre les assurances de M. Weston sur l'equivalence des deux pieces.

eng: "You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss Coxes five," had been repeated many times over.
fr: Puis commenca l'enumeration des invites : -- Vous, Mlle Smith, Mlle Fairfax, les deux demoiselles Cox, cinq, recapitula plusieurs fois Frank Churchill.

eng: "And there will be the two Gilberts, young Cox, my father, and myself, besides Mr. Knightley.
fr: Du cote masculin, il y aura les deux Gilbert, le jeune Cox, mon pere et moi, outre M. Knightley.

eng: Yes, that will be quite enough for pleasure.
fr: Ce sera suffisant pour l'agrement et il y aura largement de la place pour cinq couples.

eng: You and Miss Smith, and Miss Fairfax, will be three, and the two Miss Coxes five; and for five couple there will be plenty of room."
fr: -- En y reflechissant, reprit M. Weston, il ne me semble guere possible de lancer des invitations pour cinq couples.

eng: But soon it came to be on one side, "But will there be good room for five couple?--I really do not think there will."
fr: Une sauterie aussi restreinte ne peut etre qu'improvisee.

eng: On another, "And after all, five couple are not enough to make it worth while to stand up. ~~~ Five couple are nothing, when one thinks seriously about it.
fr: On decouvrit alors que Mlle Gilberte etait attendue chez son frere et l'existence d'un autre jeune Cox ; M. Weston nomma une famille de cousins qui devaient etre inclus dans l'invitation.

eng: It will not do to _invite_ five couple. ~~~ It can be allowable only as the thought of the moment."
fr: Finalement on arriva a dix couples au moins et il fallut songer au moyen de les faire tenir dans l'espace disponible.

eng: Somebody said that _Miss_ Gilbert was expected at her brother's, and must be invited with the rest.
fr: Les portes des deux chambres se faisaient precisement vis-a-vis : -- Ne pourrait-on danser dans les deux chambres a travers le passage ?

eng: Somebody else believed _Mrs_.
fr: suggera Frank Churchill.

eng: Gilbert would have danced the other evening, if she had been asked.
fr: On eut vite fait de s'apercevoir des inconvenients de cette solution.

eng: A word was put in for a second young Cox; and at last, Mr. Weston naming one family of cousins who must be included, and another of very old acquaintance who could not be left out, it became a certainty that the five couple would be at least ten, and a very interesting speculation in what possible manner they could be disposed of. ~~~ The doors of the two rooms were just opposite each other. ~~~ "Might not they use both rooms, and dance across the passage?"

It seemed the best scheme; and yet it was not so good but that many of them wanted a better. ~~~ Emma said it would be awkward; Mrs. Weston was in distress about the supper; and Mr. Woodhouse opposed it earnestly, on the score of health.
fr: Mme Weston se desesperait de ne plus avoir de place pour le souper et la seule idee du couloir affectait tellement M. Woodhouse qu'on dut renoncer definitivement a ce plan.

eng: It made him so very unhappy, indeed, that it could not be persevered in.
"Oh!
fr: -- Oh non !

eng: no," said he; "it would be the extreme of imprudence.
fr: dit-il, ce serait de la plus extreme imprudence.

eng: I could not bear it for Emma!--Emma is not strong. ~~~ She would catch a dreadful cold. ~~~ So would poor little Harriet.
fr: Emma n'est pas forte, elle prendrait un rhume terrible ; la pauvre petite Henriette egalement.

eng: So you would all. ~~~ Mrs. Weston, you would be quite laid up; do not let them talk of such a wild thing. ~~~ Pray do not let them talk of it.
fr: Madame Weston, vous seriez certainement forcee de vous coucher ; ne les laissez pas parler d'une chose aussi absurde, je vous en prie.

eng: That young man (speaking lower) is very thoughtless. ~~~ Do not tell his father, but that young man is not quite the thing.
fr: Ce jeune homme, ajouta-t-il en baissant la voix, est etourdi ; il a laisse les portes ouvertes ce soir a plusieurs reprises tres inconsiderement ; il ne pense pas aux courants d'air.

eng: He has been opening the doors very often this evening, and keeping them open very inconsiderately. ~~~ He does not think of the draught.
fr: Je ne voudrais pas vous indisposer contre lui, mais il n'est pas, je regrette de le dire, tout a fait ce qu'il devrait etre.

eng: I do not mean to set you against him, but indeed he is not quite the thing!" ~~~ Mrs. Weston was sorry for such a charge.
fr: Mme Weston fut desolee d'entendre ce requisitoire ; elle prevoyait les consequences qu'une pareille opinion pouvait avoir un jour ou l'autre et elle fit tout son possible pour effacer cette mauvaise impression.

eng: She knew the importance of it, and said every thing in her power to do it away.
fr: Toutes les portes furent fermees et on renonca au couloir.

eng: Every door was now closed, the passage plan given up, and the first scheme of dancing only in the room they were in resorted to again; and with such good-will on Frank Churchill's part, that the space which a quarter of an hour before had been deemed barely sufficient for five couple, was now endeavoured to be made out quite enough for ten.
fr: Il fallut revenir a la conception primitive ; Frank Churchill y mit tant de bonne volonte que l'espace juge a peine suffisant pour cinq couples, un quart d'heure auparavant, lui paraissait maintenant pouvoir en contenir dix.

eng: "We were too magnificent," said he. ~~~ "We allowed unnecessary room.
fr: -- Nous avons ete trop genereux, dit-il dans nos appreciations des distances.

eng: Ten couple may stand here very well."
fr: Dix couples pourront parfaitement evoluer ici.

eng: Emma demurred.
fr: Emma hesita.

eng: "It would be a crowd--a sad crowd; and what could be worse than dancing without space to turn in?"
fr: -- Quel plaisir, dit-elle peut-il y avoir a danser sans l'espace necessaire ?

eng: "Very true," he gravely replied; "it was very bad."
fr: -- C'est juste, reprit-il gravement ; c'est un grand inconvenient.

eng: But still he went on measuring, and still he ended with, "I think there will be very tolerable room for ten couple."
fr: Il n'en continua pas moins a prendre des mesures et, pour conclure, il ajouta : -- Somme toute, je crois qu'a la rigueur, on pourrait tenir dix couples.

eng: "No, no," said she, "you are quite unreasonable.
fr: -- Non, non, repondit Emma, vous etes tout a fait deraisonnable.

eng: It would be dreadful to be standing so close!
fr: Ce serait une cohue resserree dans une petite piece.

eng: Nothing can be farther from pleasure than to be dancing in a crowd--and a crowd in a little room!"
"There is no denying it," he replied. ~~~ "I agree with you exactly.
fr: -- Une cohue resserree dans une petite piece !

eng: A crowd in a little room--Miss Woodhouse, you have the art of giving pictures in a few words.
fr: Mademoiselle Woodhouse, vous avez l'art de peindre un tableau en quelques mots.

eng: Exquisite, quite exquisite!--Still, however, having proceeded so far, one is unwilling to give the matter up. ~~~ It would be a disappointment to my father--and altogether--I do not know that--I am rather of opinion that ten couple might stand here very well."
fr: Neanmoins, au point ou nous en sommes, je ne me sens pas le courage de renoncer a ce projet ; ce serait un desappointement pour mon pere et je ne vois pas d'obstacle insurmontable. ~~~ Ils se separerent sans avoir rien decide.

eng: Emma perceived that the nature of his gallantry was a little self-willed, and that he would rather oppose than lose the pleasure of dancing with her; but she took the compliment, and forgave the rest.
fr: Dans l'apres-midi du lendemain, Frank Churchill arriva a Hartfield avec un sourire de satisfaction sur les levres : il venait en effet proposer une amelioration.

eng: Had she intended ever to _marry_ him, it might have been worth while to pause and consider, and try to understand the value of his preference, and the character of his temper; but for all the purposes of their acquaintance, he was quite amiable enough.
fr: -- Eh bien !

eng: Before the middle of the next day, he was at Hartfield; and he entered the room with such an agreeable smile as certified the continuance of the scheme.
It soon appeared that he came to announce an improvement.
"Well, Miss Woodhouse," he almost immediately began, "your inclination for dancing has not been quite frightened away, I hope, by the terrors of my father's little rooms.
fr: Mademoiselle Woodhouse, commenca-t-il aussitot, j'espere que votre gout pour la danse n'a pas ete completement mis en fuite par l'horreur de l'exiguite des salons de mon pere.

eng: I bring a new proposal on the subject:--a thought of my father's, which waits only your approbation to be acted upon.
fr: J'apporte de nouvelles propositions : c'est une idee de mon pere, et nous n'attendons que votre approbation pour la realiser.

eng: May I hope for the honour of your hand for the two first dances of this little projected ball, to be given, not at Randalls, but at the Crown Inn?"
fr: Me ferez-vous l'honneur de m'accorder les deux premieres danses de ce bal qu'il est maintenant question de donner, non pas a Randalls, mais a l'hotel de la Couronne ?

eng: "The Crown!"
fr: -- A la Couronne !

eng: "Yes; if you and Mr. Woodhouse see no objection, and I trust you cannot, my father hopes his friends will be so kind as to visit him there.
fr: -- Oui, si vous et M. Woodhouse n'y voyez pas d'objection. ~~~ Mon pere espere que ses amis voudront bien etre ses hotes dans ce local.

eng: Better accommodations, he can promise them, and not a less grateful welcome than at Randalls.
fr: Il peut leur garantir des conditions plus favorables et un accueil non moins cordial.

eng: It is his own idea. ~~~ Mrs. Weston sees no objection to it, provided you are satisfied.
fr: Mme Weston accepte cet arrangement a condition que vous soyez satisfaite.

eng: This is what we all feel.
Oh! ~~~ you were perfectly right!
fr: Vous aviez parfaitement raison !

eng: Ten couple, in either of the Randalls rooms, would have been insufferable!--Dreadful!--I felt how right you were the whole time, but was too anxious for securing _any_ _thing_ to like to yield.
fr: Dix couples, dans l'un ou l'autre des salons de Randalls, c'eut ete insupportable, impossible !

eng: Is not it a good exchange?--You consent--I hope you consent?"
fr: Je m'en rendais compte de mon cote, mais je desirais trop arriver a un resultat pour vouloir ceder.

eng: "It appears to me a plan that nobody can object to, if Mr. and Mrs. Weston do not.
fr: Ne voyez-vous pas comme moi les avantages de cette nouvelle combinaison ?

eng: I think it admirable; and, as far as I can answer for myself, shall be most happy--It seems the only improvement that could be. ~~~ Papa, do you not think it an excellent improvement?"
fr: -- Pour ma part, je serais tres heureuse... Papa, est-ce que vous n'approuvez pas aussi ?

eng: She was obliged to repeat and explain it, before it was fully comprehended; and then, being quite new, farther representations were necessary to make it acceptable.
"No; he thought it very far from an improvement--a very bad plan--much worse than the other. ~~~ A room at an inn was always damp and dangerous; never properly aired, or fit to be inhabited.
fr: Apres avoir demande et recu des explications supplementaires, M. Woodhouse donna son avis : -- En verite, un salon dans un hotel est toujours humide ; on n'aere jamais suffisamment, et la piece ne peut etre habitable.

eng: If they must dance, they had better dance at Randalls.
fr: Si vous devez danser, il vaudrait mieux que ce fut a Randalls.

eng: He had never been in the room at the Crown in his life--did not know the people who kept it by sight.--Oh!
fr: Je n'ai jamais mis le pied dans cet hotel.

eng: no--a very bad plan.
fr: Tout le monde s'enrhumera.

eng: They would catch worse colds at the Crown than anywhere." ~~~ "I was going to observe, sir," said Frank Churchill, "that one of the great recommendations of this change would be the very little danger of any body's catching cold--so much less danger at the Crown than at Randalls!
fr: -- J'allais vous faire observer, Monsieur, dit Frank Churchill, qu'un des avantages de ce changement de local serait precisement d'ecarter tout danger de prendre froid ; M. Perry pourrait perdre a ce changement, mais personne d'autre n'aurait a le regretter.

eng: Mr. Perry might have reason to regret the alteration, but nobody else could."
fr: -- Monsieur, reprit M. Woodhouse avec chaleur, vous vous meprenez singulierement sur le caractere de M. Perry : M. Perry est extremement tourmente quand un de nous tombe malade.

eng: "Sir," said Mr. Woodhouse, rather warmly, "you are very much mistaken if you suppose Mr. Perry to be that sort of character.
fr: Mais je ne puis comprendre comment un salon d'hotel peut vous paraitre un meilleur abri que la maison de votre pere.

eng: Mr. Perry is extremely concerned when any of us are ill. ~~~ But I do not understand how the room at the Crown can be safer for you than your father's house."
fr: -- En raison meme de sa grandeur, Monsieur ; nous n'aurons pas besoin d'ouvrir les fenetres, une seule fois et c'est precisement cette mauvaise habitude de laisser penetrer l'air de la nuit dans une chambre ou se trouvent des gens en transpiration qui est la cause de la plupart des refroidissements !

eng: "From the very circumstance of its being larger, sir.
fr: -- Ouvrir les fenetres !

eng: We shall have no occasion to open the windows at all--not once the whole evening; and it is that dreadful habit of opening the windows, letting in cold air upon heated bodies, which (as you well know, sir) does the mischief."
"Open the windows!--but surely, Mr. Churchill, nobody would think of opening the windows at Randalls.
fr: Personne ne songerait a ouvrir les fenetres a Randalls.

eng: Nobody could be so imprudent!
fr: Je n'ai jamais entendu parler d'une chose pareille.

eng: I never heard of such a thing.
fr: Danser les fenetres ouvertes !

eng: Dancing with open windows!--I am sure, neither your father nor Mrs. Weston (poor Miss Taylor that was) would suffer it."
fr: Ni votre pere ni Mme Weston - cette pauvre Mlle Taylor - ne tolereraient cette maniere d'agir.

eng: "Ah!
fr: -- Ah !

eng: sir--but a thoughtless young person will sometimes step behind a window-curtain, and throw up a sash, without its being suspected.
fr: monsieur... mais quelque jeunesse inconsideree se glisse parfois derriere le rideau et releve un chassis sans y etre autorisee.

eng: I have often known it done myself."
fr: Je l'ai souvent vu faire moi-meme.

eng: "Have you indeed, sir?--Bless me! ~~~ I never could have supposed it.
fr: -- Est-ce possible, Monsieur, je ne l'aurais jamais cru ; mais je vis a l'ecart et je suis souvent etonne de ce que j'apprends.

eng: But I live out of the world, and am often astonished at what I hear.
fr: Neanmoins, cette circonstance merite consideration et peut-etre le moment venu...

eng: However, this does make a difference; and, perhaps, when we come to talk it over--but these sort of things require a good deal of consideration.
fr: Ce genre de projet demande a etre murement pese ; on ne peut prendre une decision a la hate.

eng: One cannot resolve upon them in a hurry.
If Mr. and Mrs. Weston will be so obliging as to call here one morning, we may talk it over, and see what can be done."
fr: Si M. et Mme Weston voulaient se donner la peine de venir me voir un de ces jours, nous pourrions examiner la question.

eng: "But, unfortunately, sir, my time is so limited--" "Oh!"
fr: -- Mais malheureusement, Monsieur, j'ai moi-meme si peu de temps... -- Il y aura, interrompit Emma, tout le temps necessaire pour discuter le sujet ; il n'y a aucune hate.

eng: interrupted Emma, "there will be plenty of time for talking every thing over. ~~~ There is no hurry at all.
fr: Si l'on peut s'arranger a l'hotel de la Couronne, papa, ce sera bien commode pour les chevaux : ils seront tout pres de leur ecurie.

eng: If it can be contrived to be at the Crown, papa, it will be very convenient for the horses.
fr: -- En effet, ma chere, c'est un point important ; non pas que James se plaigne jamais, mais il importe de menager nos chevaux.

eng: They will be so near their own stable." ~~~ "So they will, my dear.
fr: Si encore j'etais sur qu'on aurait soin de bien aerer le salon !

eng: That is a great thing.
fr: Mais peut-on se fier a Mme Stokes ?

eng: Not that James ever complains; but it is right to spare our horses when we can.
If I could be sure of the rooms being thoroughly aired--but is Mrs. Stokes to be trusted?
I doubt it. ~~~ I do not know her, even by sight."
fr: J'en doute : je ne la connais meme pas de vue.

eng: "I can answer for every thing of that nature, sir, because it will be under Mrs. Weston's care. ~~~ Mrs. Weston undertakes to direct the whole."
fr: -- Je puis me porter garant que toutes les precautions seront prises, Monsieur, reprit Frank Churchill... Mme Weston surveillera tout elle-meme.

eng: "There, papa!--Now you must be satisfied--Our own dear Mrs. Weston, who is carefulness itself.
fr: -- Dans ce cas, papa, vous devez etre tranquille : notre chere Mme Weston est le soin personnifie.

eng: Do not you remember what Mr. Perry said, so many years ago, when I had the measles? ~~~ 'If _Miss_ _Taylor_ undertakes to wrap Miss Emma up, you need not have any fears, sir.'
fr: M. Perry ne disait-il pas, quand j'ai eu la rougeole il y a tant d'annees : << Si Mlle Taylor prend la responsabilite de tenir Mlle Emma au chaud, il n'y a pas a se tourmenter !

eng: How often have I heard you speak of it as such a compliment to her!"
fr: >> Cette preuve de confiance vous avait frappe.

eng: "Aye, very true.
fr: -- C'est bien vrai !

eng: Mr. Perry did say so.
fr: Je n'ai pas oublie.

eng: I shall never forget it. ~~~ Poor little Emma!
fr: Pauvre petite Emma, vous etiez bien malade !

eng: You were very bad with the measles; that is, you would have been very bad, but for Perry's great attention.
fr: Du moins, vous l'auriez ete sans les soins de Perry : il vint quatre fois par jour pendant une semaine.

eng: He came four times a day for a week.
fr: La rougeole est une terrible maladie.

eng: He said, from the first, it was a very good sort--which was our great comfort; but the measles are a dreadful complaint.
I hope whenever poor Isabella's little ones have the measles, she will send for Perry."
fr: J'espere qu'Isabelle, si ses petits enfants ont la rougeole, fera appeler Perry.

eng: "My father and Mrs. Weston are at the Crown at this moment," said Frank Churchill, "examining the capabilities of the house.
fr: -- Mon pere et Mme Weston sont en ce moment a l'hotel de la Couronne, en train d'etudier les lieux.

eng: I left them there and came on to Hartfield, impatient for your opinion, and hoping you might be persuaded to join them and give your advice on the spot. ~~~ I was desired to say so from both.
fr: Ils desirent connaitre votre opinion, Mlle Woodhouse, et ils seraient heureux si vous consentiez a venir les rejoindre.

eng: It would be the greatest pleasure to them, if you could allow me to attend you there.
fr: Rien ne peut etre fait d'une facon definitive sans vous.

eng: They can do nothing satisfactorily without you."
fr: Si vous le permettez, je vous accompagnerai jusqu'a l'hotel.

eng: Emma was most happy to be called to such a council; and her father, engaging to think it all over while she was gone, the two young people set off together without delay for the Crown.
fr: Emma fut tres contente d'etre appelee a prendre part a ce conseil ; son pere promit de considerer le probleme pendant leur absence et les deux jeunes gens se mirent en route.

eng: There were Mr. and Mrs. Weston; delighted to see her and receive her approbation, very busy and very happy in their different way; she, in some little distress; and he, finding every thing perfect.
fr: M. et Mme Weston furent enchantes de l'approbation d'Emma ; ils etaient tres affaires ; Mme Weston n'etait pas absolument satisfaite ; mais lui trouvait tout parfait.

eng: "Emma," said she, "this paper is worse than I expected. ~~~ Look! ~~~ in places you see it is dreadfully dirty; and the wainscot is more yellow and forlorn than any thing I could have imagined."
fr: -- Emma, dit Mme Weston, ce papier est en plus mauvais etat que je ne pensais : par endroits il est extremement sale ; et la boiserie a une teinte jaune.

eng: "My dear, you are too particular," said her husband. ~~~ "What does all that signify?
fr: -- Ma chere, vous etes trop meticuleuse, reprit son mari, c'est un detail sans importance.

eng: You will see nothing of it by candlelight. ~~~ It will be as clean as Randalls by candlelight. ~~~ We never see any thing of it on our club-nights."
fr: On n'y verra rien a la lumiere des bougies : nous ne nous apercevons jamais de rien les jours de nos reunions de whist !

eng: The ladies here probably exchanged looks which meant, "Men never know when things are dirty or not;" and the gentlemen perhaps thought each to himself, "Women will have their little nonsenses and needless cares."
One perplexity, however, arose, which the gentlemen did not disdain. ~~~ It regarded a supper-room.
fr: Une autre question se posa relativement a l'emplacement de la table du souper.

eng: At the time of the ballroom's being built, suppers had not been in question; and a small card-room adjoining, was the only addition.
fr: L'unique chambre contigue a la salle de bal etait fort petite et devait servir de salon de jeu.

eng: What was to be done? ~~~ This card-room would be wanted as a card-room now; or, if cards were conveniently voted unnecessary by their four selves, still was it not too small for any comfortable supper?
Another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose; but it was at the other end of the house, and a long awkward passage must be gone through to get at it.
fr: Une autre piece beaucoup plus vaste etait mise a leur disposition, mais elle etait situee a l'extremite d'un couloir.

eng: This made a difficulty. ~~~ Mrs. Weston was afraid of draughts for the young people in that passage; and neither Emma nor the gentlemen could tolerate the prospect of being miserably crowded at supper. ~~~ Mrs. Weston proposed having no regular supper; merely sandwiches, &c., set out in the little room; but that was scouted as a wretched suggestion.
fr: Mme Weston craignait les courants d'air pour les jeunes gens dans le passage ; dans un but de simplification, elle proposa de ne pas avoir un veritable souper, mais simplement un buffet avec des sandwiches, etc., dresse dans la petite chambre, mais cette idee fut aussitot ecartee comme pitoyable : un bal sans souper assis fut juge contraire a tous les droits de l'homme et de la femme ; Mme Weston dut promettre de ne plus y faire allusion.

eng: A private dance, without sitting down to supper, was pronounced an infamous fraud upon the rights of men and women; and Mrs. Weston must not speak of it again.
fr: Elle changea alors d'expedient et dit : -- Il me semble qu'a la rigueur nous pourrions tous tenir ici ; nous ne serons pas si nombreux.

eng: She then took another line of expediency, and looking into the doubtful room, observed, "I do not think it _is_ so very small.
fr: Mais Emma et les messieurs, etaient decides a etre installes confortablement pour souper.

eng: We shall not be many, you know." ~~~ And Mr. Weston at the same time, walking briskly with long steps through the passage, was calling out, "You talk a great deal of the length of this passage, my dear.
fr: M. Weston se met a parcourir le couloir et cria : -- Vous avez parle de la longueur du couloir, ma chere, mais a bien considerer ce n'est rien du tout et on est a l'abri du vent de l'escalier.

eng: It is a mere nothing after all; and not the least draught from the stairs."
"I wish," said Mrs. Weston, "one could know which arrangement our guests in general would like best.
fr: -- Je voudrais bien savoir, dit Mme Weston, quel arrangement nos hotes prefereraient.

eng: To do what would be most generally pleasing must be our object--if one could but tell what that would be."
fr: Notre desir est de contenter tout le monde et si nous pouvions connaitre l'opinion generale, je serais plus tranquille.

eng: "Yes, very true," cried Frank, "very true. ~~~ You want your neighbours' opinions.
fr: -- C'est juste, dit Frank, on pourrait prendre l'avis de nos voisins, des Cole, par exemple, qui n'habitent pas loin.

eng: I do not wonder at you.
fr: Irai-je les trouver ?

eng: If one could ascertain what the chief of them--the Coles, for instance.
They are not far off.
fr: Et aussi celui de Mlle Bates.

eng: Shall I call upon them? ~~~ Or Miss Bates?
fr: Elle demeure encore plus pres.

eng: She is still nearer.--And I do not know whether Miss Bates is not as likely to understand the inclinations of the rest of the people as any body.
fr: Il me semble que Mlle Bates serait assez capable de donner la note exacte, une sorte de moyenne ; si j'allais prier Mlle Bates de venir ?

eng: I think we do want a larger council.
Suppose I go and invite Miss Bates to join us?" ~~~ "Well--if you please," said Mrs. Weston rather hesitating, "if you think she will be of any use."
fr: -- Si vous croyez, reprit Mme Weston avec un peu d'hesitation, si vous croyez qu'elle peut nous etre utile.

eng: "You will get nothing to the purpose from Miss Bates," said Emma. ~~~ "She will be all delight and gratitude, but she will tell you nothing. ~~~ She will not even listen to your questions.
fr: -- Vous n'obtiendrez aucun eclaircissement de Mlle Bates, reprit Emma, elle se confondra en remerciements et en expressions de reconnaissance, mais elle ne dira rien ; elle n'ecoutera meme pas vos questions.

eng: I see no advantage in consulting Miss Bates."
fr: Je ne vois aucun avantage a consulter Mlle Bates.

eng: "But she is so amusing, so extremely amusing!
fr: -- Mais elle est si amusante, si extremement amusante !

eng: I am very fond of hearing Miss Bates talk.
And I need not bring the whole family, you know."
fr: J'aime beaucoup entendre parler Mlle Bates.

eng: Here Mr. Weston joined them, and on hearing what was proposed, gave it his decided approbation.
fr: -- A ce moment, M. Weston arriva et ayant ete mis au courant de ce dont il s'agissait, donna son entiere approbation.

eng: "Aye, do, Frank.--Go and fetch Miss Bates, and let us end the matter at once. ~~~ She will enjoy the scheme, I am sure; and I do not know a properer person for shewing us how to do away difficulties. ~~~ Fetch Miss Bates.
fr: -- Certainement, Frank, allez chercher Mlle Bates ; elle approuvera notre plan, j'en suis sur ; je ne connais pas une personne plus apte a denouer les difficultes.

eng: We are growing a little too nice.
fr: Nous faisons trop d'embarras.

eng: She is a standing lesson of how to be happy.
fr: Elle nous enseignera la maniere d'etre content de tout.

eng: But fetch them both.
fr: Mais, amenez-les toutes les deux.

eng: Invite them both." ~~~ "Both sir!
fr: -- Toutes les deux, Monsieur !

eng: Can the old lady?"...
fr: Est-ce que la vieille dame... ?

eng: "The old lady!
fr: -- La vieille dame !

eng: No, the young lady, to be sure.
fr: Mais non ; je fais allusion a la jeune.

eng: I shall think you a great blockhead, Frank, if you bring the aunt without the niece." ~~~ "Oh!
fr: Je vous considererais comme un sot si vous ameniez la tante sans la niece.

eng: I beg your pardon, sir. ~~~ I did not immediately recollect. ~~~ Undoubtedly if you wish it, I will endeavour to persuade them both."
fr: -- Excusez ma distraction, Monsieur ; puisque vous le desirez, je m'efforcerai de les amener l'une et l'autre.

eng: And away he ran.
fr: Et il partit sur le champ.

eng: Long before he reappeared, attending the short, neat, brisk-moving aunt, and her elegant niece,--Mrs. Weston, like a sweet-tempered woman and a good wife, had examined the passage again, and found the evils of it much less than she had supposed before--indeed very trifling; and here ended the difficulties of decision.
fr: Bien avant le retour de Frank Churchill, Mme Weston avait examine de nouveau le couloir et en femme soumise s'etait rangee a l'avis de son mari ; en consequence il fut decide que la salle a manger serait utilisee.

eng: All the rest, in speculation at least, was perfectly smooth. ~~~ All the minor arrangements of table and chair, lights and music, tea and supper, made themselves; or were left as mere trifles to be settled at any time between Mrs. Weston and Mrs.
fr: Tout le reste du programme, du moins en theorie, paraissait extremement simple : on se mit d'accord sur l'eclairage, la musique, le the, le souper ; Mme Weston et Mme Stokes devaient resoudre les petites difficultes qui pourraient se presenter par la suite.

eng: Stokes.--Every body invited, was certainly to come; Frank had already written to Enscombe to propose staying a few days beyond his fortnight, which could not possibly be refused.
fr: On savait pouvoir compter sur tous les invites ; Frank avait deja ecrit a Enscombe pour demander de rester quelques jours de plus et il escomptait une reponse favorable.

eng: And a delightful dance it was to be. ~~~ Most cordially, when Miss Bates arrived, did she agree that it must.
fr: Mlle Bates, en arrivant, ne put qu'apporter ses felicitations : elles furent du reste beaucoup mieux accueillies que ne l'eussent probablement ete ses conseils.

eng: As a counsellor she was not wanted; but as an approver, (a much safer character,) she was truly welcome.
fr: Pendant une demi-heure encore, ils allerent et vinrent a travers les pieces et diverses ameliorations de detail furent suggerees.

eng: Her approbation, at once general and minute, warm and incessant, could not but please; and for another half-hour they were all walking to and fro, between the different rooms, some suggesting, some attending, and all in happy enjoyment of the future.
fr: Au moment de l'adieu, Frank Churchill renouvela son invitation a Emma pour les premieres danses ; peu apres celle-ci entendit M. Weston murmurer a l'oreille de sa femme : << Naturellement, ma chere, il l'a invitee !

eng: The party did not break up without Emma's being positively secured for the two first dances by the hero of the evening, nor without her overhearing Mr. Weston whisper to his wife, "He has asked her, my dear.
fr: >> XXX Au bout de quelques jours arriva une lettre d'Enscombe accordant l'autorisation demandee ; les termes de la reponse indiquaient que les Churchill n'etaient pas satisfaits de cette prolongation de sejour, mais ils ne s'y opposerent pas.

eng: That's right. ~~~ I knew he would!"
fr: Tout paraissait donc marcher a souhait.

eng: CHAPTER XII One thing only was wanting to make the prospect of the ball completely satisfactory to Emma--its being fixed for a day within the granted term of Frank Churchill's stay in Surry; for, in spite of Mr. Weston's confidence, she could not think it so very impossible that the Churchills might not allow their nephew to remain a day beyond his fortnight.
But this was not judged feasible.
fr: La bonne humeur etait generale.

eng: The preparations must take their time, nothing could be properly ready till the third week were entered on, and for a few days they must be planning, proceeding and hoping in uncertainty--at the risk--in her opinion, the great risk, of its being all in vain.
Enscombe however was gracious, gracious in fact, if not in word.
His wish of staying longer evidently did not please; but it was not opposed.

All was safe and prosperous; and as the removal of one solicitude generally makes way for another, Emma, being now certain of her ball, began to adopt as the next vexation Mr. Knightley's provoking indifference about it.

Either because he did not dance himself, or because the plan had been formed without his being consulted, he seemed resolved that it should not interest him, determined against its exciting any present curiosity, or affording him any future amusement.
To her voluntary communications Emma could get no more approving reply, than, "Very well.
fr: Jane Fairfax elle-meme se montrait enthousiaste, elle en devenait animee, franche et dit spontanement : << Oh !

eng: If the Westons think it worth while to be at all this trouble for a few hours of noisy entertainment, I have nothing to say against it, but that they shall not chuse pleasures for me.--Oh!

yes, I must be there; I could not refuse; and I will keep as much awake as I can; but I would rather be at home, looking over William Larkins's week's account; much rather, I confess.--Pleasure in seeing dancing!--not I, indeed--I never look at it--I do not know who does.--Fine dancing, I believe, like virtue, must be its own reward.
Those who are standing by are usually thinking of something very different." ~~~ This Emma felt was aimed at her; and it made her quite angry.
fr: mademoiselle Woodhouse j'espere qu'il n'arrivera rien pour empecher cette reunion ; je m'en fais, je l'avoue, un veritable plaisir.

eng: It was not in compliment to Jane Fairfax however that he was so indifferent, or so indignant; he was not guided by _her_ feelings in reprobating the ball, for _she_ enjoyed the thought of it to an extraordinary degree.
It made her animated--open hearted--she voluntarily said;-- "Oh!
fr: >> Seul M. Knightley continuait a ne laisser paraitre aucun interet.

eng: Miss Woodhouse, I hope nothing may happen to prevent the ball.
fr: En reponse aux communications d'Emma, il se contentait de repondre : -- Tres bien.

eng: What a disappointment it would be! ~~~ I do look forward to it, I own, with _very_ great pleasure."
fr: S'il plait aux Weston de se donner tant de peine pour quelques heures d'un amusement bruyant, c'est leur affaire ; mais il ne depend pas d'eux que j'y prenne plaisir.

eng: It was not to oblige Jane Fairfax therefore that he would have preferred the society of William Larkins.
fr: Naturellement, je ne peux pas refuser ; je ferai de mon mieux pour rester eveille ; toutefois, j'aurais prefere de beaucoup rester a la maison pour examiner les comptes de William Larkins.

eng: No!--she was more and more convinced that Mrs. Weston was quite mistaken in that surmise. ~~~ There was a great deal of friendly and of compassionate attachment on his side--but no love.
fr: Je ne danse pas et je ne trouve aucun charme au role de spectateur ; du reste, la plupart de ceux qui ne prennent pas une part active au bal partagent mon indifference : bien danser procure sans doute une satisfaction interieure comme la vertu !

eng: Alas!
fr: Helas !

eng: there was soon no leisure for quarrelling with Mr. Knightley.
Two days of joyful security were immediately followed by the over-throw of every thing.

A letter arrived from Mr. Churchill to urge his nephew's instant return. ~~~ Mrs. Churchill was unwell--far too unwell to do without him; she had been in a very suffering state (so said her husband) when writing to her nephew two days before, though from her usual unwillingness to give pain, and constant habit of never thinking of herself, she had not mentioned it; but now she was too ill to trifle, and must entreat him to set off for Enscombe without delay.
fr: toute raison de divergence avec M. Knightley devait bientot disparaitre : apres deux jours d'une fausse securite, Frank Churchill recut une lettre de son oncle le priant de revenir sans delai : << Mme Churchill etait tres malade ; deja fort souffrante en repondant a son neveu, elle n'avait pas voulu, dans son desir de lui eviter un desappointement, faire allusion a son etat de sante.
